Balcarres,
Oct 26th 1933.

The Secretary.
Department of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Ont.

Re:- 0176 Georgina Kakewayess

Dear Sir;-

I am in receipt of a communication from Indian Agent Dodds with reference to the discharge of the above noted student of this School.

In reply I would advise that this girl was married on April 26th, grant for 26 days was requested for her on the June quarter return.

Through an oversight on my part in compiling the June quarter return this girl's discharge was not requested, this is regretted, and I now recommend that she be discharged as at April 26th 1933.

Yours truly,

[Signature]
Principal.
Ottawa, November 7, 1933.

Sir:

With reference to official letter of the 20th ultimo in which information was requested regarding Georgina Kakewayess, No. 0176, of the File Hills Residential School, I beg to say that a letter has been received from the Principal in which he states that this girl was married on April 26th, last. Her discharge from the File Hills School is, therefore, approved, and you may so inform Mr. Rhodes.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Muscow, Sask.

Sir:

The Department is in receipt of the December quarter return of the File Hills Residential School.

Please inform the Principal that the discharge of pupil No. 161 is approved, and his number should be omitted from future returns.

In checking the return it is found that two pupils were given certain register numbers on admission and on the December quarter return these numbers have been changed. It is most important that the register number given a pupil on entrance should be retained for the whole period of residence and dropped on discharge.

Ottawa, March 3, 1934.

Rev. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, protesting against the admission of Edith Star to the File Hills Residential School.

The application for the admission of this girl to the File Hills School was forwarded to the Department last December. The form stated that her religion is "Protestant" and was signed by her father and approved by the Indian Agent.

However, in view of your protest, I am immediately writing Mr. Agent Dodds.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. G. Leonard, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,
Lebret, Sask.
Ottawa, March 3, 1934.

Sir:

In your letter of December 6th, last, you forwarded an application and certificate of health for the admission of Edith Star, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ed. Star, to the File Hills Residential School. The application form stated that the girl's religion is "Protestant", and the form was apparently signed by the father. Therefore, the application form appeared in order and her admission was approved.

The Department is now in receipt of a protest against her admission to that school. Our informant states that both the parents of this girl are Roman Catholic.

Please make immediate enquiries and let the Department have any information you obtain. In replying, you should state what action you took before signing the application for her admission to File Hills to assure yourself that the statements made on the application form were correct.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Geo. A. Dodds, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Balcarres, Sask.
Balcarres, Sask.,
March 8, 1934.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter lll-1-10, dated the 3rd instant, with regard to Edith Starr, I beg to advise that this application was signed by the father Edward Starr, who is the Interpreter at this Agency.

This man is a Protestant, and is a graduate of File Hills Residential School. His wife was a Roman Catholic. These mixed marriages, are, as you know, the cause of a great deal of trouble with regard to the religion of the children as both denominations claim them. In the far greater number of cases the children attend the R.C. School. In the case of these mixed marriages I have always found it wisest not to interfere at all but to allow the parents to choose which school they would send their children to.

Edith Starr started to attend File Hills School in August, 1932, but she was not a residential pupil as she came home to her meals and slept at home. He mother died last September and her father afterwards had her admitted to File Hills School. Both Father Comeau and Father Leonard have been to see Starr with regard to his daughter and have asked him to sign application forms to have her admitted to Qu'Appelle School and he has consistently refused to do so. I have him in the office again this morning, read him your letter and asked him if he was a Roman Catholic. He denied it and stated further that he does not intend to allow to have his child taken away from File Hills School. I recommend that she be left where she is.

I might add that Mrs. Starr was a widow when she married Edward Starr and had three children by her former husband. Ed. Starr never interfered with these children in any way and they were educated at Qu'Appelle School. The girl above referred to is Starr's only own child.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Your obedient servant,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, March 14, 1934.

Reverend Sir:

With further reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, protesting against the admission of Edith Starr to the File Hills Residential School, I beg to say that the following report has been received from Mr. Agent Dodds—

"This man is a Protestant and is a graduate of File Hills Residential School. His wife was a Roman Catholic. These mixed marriages are, as you know, the cause of a great deal of trouble with regard to the religion of the children, as both denominations claim them. In the far greater number of cases the children attend the R.C. School. In the case of these mixed marriages I have always found it wisest not to interfere at all but to allow the parents to choose which school they would send their children to.

"Edith Starr started to attend File Hills School in August, 1932, but she was not a residential pupil as she came home to her meals and slept at home. Her mother died last September and her father afterwards had her admitted to File Hills School. Both Father Comeau and Father Leonard have been to see Starr with regard to his daughter and have asked him to sign application forms to have her admitted to Qu'Appelle School, and he has consistently refused to do so. I have him in the office again this morning; read him your letter and asked him if he was a Roman Catholic. He denied it and stated further that he does not intend to allow his child taken away from File Hills School. I recommend that she be left where she is.

"I might add that Mrs. Starr was a widow when she married Edward Starr and had three children by her former husband. Ed. Starr never interfered with these children in any way and they were educated at Qu'Appelle School. The girl above referred to is Starr's only own child."

In view of the above information, the Department considers that this girl should remain in the File Hills School.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. G. Leonard, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School,
Lebret, Sask.

Dear Sir:

With further reference to your letter of March 14th, No.111-1-10, with regard to the admission of Ethel Star to the File Hills School, I note that Mr. Fodde refers to Ms. Star as a Protestant and to his marriage as a "mixed marriage". This is not the case. Ms. Star was converted before her marriage and was received into the Roman Catholic Church on May 7th, 1919, by Rev. Father Kalmas, his Godparents were John Bellegarde and Marie Louise Dumont. On the same day he married Eliza Cayen, witnesses - Magloire Bellegarde and William Desnami. This is recorded in the Church Register and can be supported by Statutory Declarations, if necessary, from the parties above mentioned. This, then, was not a mixed marriage as both parties were Roman Catholics.

I am enclosing Statutory Declaration from Rev. Father Jeannotte to show that he was practicing the Catholic Religion and was considered a Catholic by the other Indians. Rev. Father Comeau, who succeeded Rev. Father Jeannotte as missionary at File Hills, also certifies that he has been practicing his religion during the two years he has been in charge. If further proof were needed to establish his religion it would be found in the fact that his nephew, Donald Star, born June 1930, (son of Sidney Star, a Protestant, and Jane Wake Up), whom he adopted, was baptized a Roman Catholic Oct. 5th, 1931. There was surely no reason for him having the boy brought up a Catholic if he himself was not a Catholic.

It would seem incredible that Mr. Fodde was not aware that Star was a Catholic, as he worked at the Agency and the Catholic Church is only a few yams from the Agency.

Mr. Fodde also makes the statement with reference to the children of mixed marriages: "In the far greater number of cases the children attend the R.C.School". It would be interesting to know where he got the statistics on this, certainly not from the records of his Agency. I can say that we have not a single pupil here who is the offspring of a mixed marriage, and the Department need only examine our Quarterly Returns to verify this. On the other hand we are aware of several attending not only File Hills School but other Protestant schools.

Mr. Fodde told Father Comeau that Ethel was only going to school during the day as her health was poor. Mr. Shores, Principal of File Hills School, made a similar statement to me. From this it would appear that they recognized her as a Roman Catholic.

I never asked Ms. Star to sign any form of admission but I simply told him he should bring his daughter to Lebret and he never gave me a definite answer, and said that his daughter was only a day pupil at File Hills.

Trusting you will reconsider your decision in this case.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter lll-l-10, dated the 13th instant, regarding Edith Starr.

I do not want to enter into any controversy with the priests or any other missionaries regarding the admittance of children to school because it will only lead to ill feeling. I think I am in the best position to judge which school a child should be sent to and I have already told the Department that I think Edith Starr should be admitted to File Hills School.

We have, on this Agency both a Roman Catholic and a United Church missionary and in a great number of cases both of them can produce records to show Indians have been baptised and are members of their church. What naturally happens is that Indians that have attended Protestant schools often attend Roman Catholic church services and those that have attended Roman Catholic schools often attend United Church services. I have seen this myself on many occasions. When this has occurred it seems that the priests have got the Indians to be baptised and then entered them as members as their church and it is this proof that the Rev. Father Leonard is advancing.

The attitude I have always taken is this. In the case where the parents are pagan I allow the children to enter any school the parents wishes. In the case where both parents have attended a Protestant School I see that the children attend the same kind of school and in the case of Roman Catholics I see the children attend a Roman Catholic School. When one of the parents is a Roman Catholic and the other a Protestant I allow the parents to decide. In far the most cases they decide to send their children to Lebret and in that case there is no trouble. When however, as in the present case, the parents decide to send the children to File Hills School the admission is always protested by the R.C. missionary or the Principal of Qu'Appelle School.

I never told the Rev. Father Comeau that Edith Starr was attending File Hills School because she was in poor health. She attended File Hills School because of the wishes of her parents and she was not admitted as a residential pupil until after her mother died. It was the desire of her mother as well as her father that Edith should attend File Hills School and she spoke to me about on many occasions.

I have had Starr in the office again today and have him to state definitely what religious denomination he belongs to and what school he wishes Edith to attend. I have had him sign a declaration to the effect that he belongs to the United Church and wishes Edith to attend File Hills School.

I also spoke to him about Donald, the child of Sidney Star he kept for a year or so and he says that if Donald was baptised as a Roman Catholic he never knew anything about it. As a matter of fact this boy has now gone home to his parents and undoubtedly when the time for him comes to attend...

14-11-34

1. In connection with the above and previous report rendered in this matter I have the honour to report that in the a.m. this date a telephone message was received at this office from Mr. Booth, Indian Agent of Qu'Appelle Agency, who informed the writer that Edward Harrald had again run away from school and was believed to be on the Muscowpetung Indian Reserve and requested that I locate this boy and bring him back. Mr. Booth also stated that a George Gambler had also run away and would most likely be on the same reserve.

2. In the a.m. same date I patrolled per pte-car to the Muscowpetung Reserve and instituted enquiries for these children, but no trace or their whereabouts could be learned and I returned to my Detachment in the p.m. same date.

15-11-34

Ottawa, March 30, 1935.

Sir:

With regard to a number of children at present in the File Hills Indian Residential School, the Department has received protests on the grounds that the parents are not recognized as Protestants.

These protests emphasize the importance of your examining all application forms very carefully and making certain that the information contained on them is correct before forwarding same to the Department. I wish to draw your special attention to the last paragraph of circular letter of November 12th, 1926, which reads as follows:

"I am particularly desirous, at the present time, of impressing on you that pupils whose eligibility is doubtful - either for religious or other reasons - must not be placed in a residential school until all the facts are known to the Department and a decision has been given."

The Department trusts that you will watch all applications in future for the admission of children to any Indian residential school, and if there is any doubt whatever regarding the eligibility of a child, the matter should be reported to the Department and our decision obtained before the child is placed in a residential school.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:-

I have the honor to reply to your letter No. 111-1-10 of the 30th ultimo regarding eligibility of children to residential schools.

I beg to say that the religious element is very strong around this section and I have to be extremely careful as to the schooling of children. I may also state that if I have any doubts the matter is referred to the Department for their decision.

As far as I know I have no doubtful cases in the File Hills Indian Residential School though there are some children in this school whose parents are of different creeds but in these cases the matter was brought to the Department's attention and their decision obtained.

I feel justified in saying that I consider the protest the Department received is not a fair protest and if there is any special case the protestee wishes to go into I shall be pleased to go into fuller details.

1. 5. Continuing the patrol to the district north of Balcarres, enquiries were made but without result, in the meantime Fort Qu'Appelle Detachment was notified as the home of these boys was on the Pasqua Indian Reserve and there was no doubt but what they were heading for home. The patrol returned to Balcarres this late p.m.

19.4.36.

6. This P.M. Dr. A. B. Simes, in charge of the File Hills Indian Hospital, called at this office personally, stating that he had located the two boys in question and was returning them to the Hospital.

Sir:

I have the honour to place the following matter before the Department.

On July 25th, last Clifford Bear No.160 of John Smith's Band, wrote me as follows:

"We have decided to put our two boys" in File Hills School, Bruce and Teresa, please make arrangements."

The Bears are very poor, they have six children, the eldest being Bruce, mentioned above, who will be nine years of age on January 2nd., next. He, Bear has a stiff knee and is unable to walk without a strong cane (stick) and cannot do any heavy work, hence their reason for asking to place their children in a Residential School, as they become of age. Which I recommend.

On August the 9th., I called on the Bears at their home where they, Bear and his wife, signed application for admission. These I immediately forwarded to Mr. F. Rhodes, Principal of the School, suggesting that he have the boys examined, and certificate of health completed before leaving Prince Albert when he came there for other pupils returning to School after the vacations.

Though informed to do so on a certain date Bear's two boys did not come to Prince Albert, and were left behind. I later saw Bear who stated he had no means of transportation from the reserve to Prince Albert, and that although he had asked another Indian to bring the boys along with his children he had not called for them. The two boys are still at the reserve, and are attending the day school there.

Mr. F. Rhodes called me on long distance phone this P.M. stating he would be at Prince Albert on Wednesday the 27th., instant, and would go from there to John Smith's Reserve for the boys, provided there is no objection to them being placed in his school, adding that he had been informed in writing that his Lordship Bishop Board, of Prince Albert objected to Anglican children from another reserve and agency being placed in his school. In reply to Mr. Rhodes I said that I had never heard of such an objection.

Mr. Rhodes then asked me if I would inform the Department on the matter, and let him know their decision before he came to Prince Albert on the 27th., stating he did not want to bring the children to File Hills, and then have them transferred somewhere else.

Dear Sir,

Mary Margaret Louis of the Pelican Lake Band, formerly pupil No. 0155 of the Onion Lake C.E. Indian Residential School, was placed in the File Hills Colony Hospital in September, 1934, for treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis.

Dr. A. B. Simes, Medical Superintendent, Qu'Appelle Indian Health Unit, now writes the Department as follows:

"Her last X-Ray plates show she is now fit to return to school but she should be checked frequently during the next six months to be certain she is not going to have a relapse.

"Mr. F. Rhodes, Principal of File Hills School, is willing to accept her as a temporary pupil, provided she is agreeable to the Department and the Anglican Church.

"If she is admitted to File Hills School she will be seen regularly by me and X-Rayed whenever necessary. Should she be sent direct to Onion Lake that would not be possible. Provided she shows no evidence of breaking down between new and summer vacation, she will be returned home and will enter Onion Lake School following the holidays.

"I would be pleased if you could inform me whether these arrangements meet with your approval or not at an early date, if possible. I am not only anxious for this girl to continue her education but her bed in the hospital is required for another urgent case."

In view of the Medical Superintendent's report, the Department is approving of this girl being placed in the File Hills Residential School until June 30th, next. If she shows no evidence of breaking down by that time, she will be returned home and you may apply for her admission to the Onion Lake C.E. Residential School after the holidays.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Re: No.75 Donald Bigknife.

Dear Sir;

The above mentioned pupil of this School is giving us a considerable amount of trouble as a habitual run-away.

This boy lives on the Starblanket Reserve on the File Hills Agency, he ran home on several occasions last spring, sometimes within a few minutes after being returned to the School, and at the present time is truant again, coming to his home at night to sleep and slipping out of the house at day-break, apparently his Parents are powerless to do anything with him.

I have conferred with Dr Doyle, Principal of the Brandon Residential School, with a view to having this boy transferred there, Dr Doyle is quite willing to take him, it is therefore recommended that he be transferred to the Brandon School, I will appreciate it if the Department will consider this and grant the necessary authority.

Accordingly, official letter of today's date is being directed to the Agent.

Reverend Sir,

I have your 10487 of the 31st ultimo, with reference to the application of the children of Alex. Nokusia for the File Hills Residential School. When the Department has before it an application where the religion is in doubt, we first give prominence to the belief of the parents. If the parents are in disagreement, the father has the right to direct the religious education of his child. If a case like this were taken to court, you would find that in law it is the wishes of the parents that would be regarded. In the Stonechild case, the parents were not in entire agreement - the father having signed a statement that he wanted his boy in the File Hills School.

Dear Sir,

The Department has received your letter of the 19th instant, also letter from Alex Nokusis, with reference to his children.

These letters have been very carefully considered and we have, also, reviewed all the correspondence at the time the two children of Nokusis were admitted to the File Hills Indian Residential School in 1931.

However, at that time the Department decided, in view of the express desire of the father to send them to File Hills, to approve the admission of the children to that school.

It is now definitely established that Nokusis desires his children educated in a school conducted under the auspices of the religion to which he belongs. It is felt that his wishes should now be respected in the same manner as they were respected in 1931 and, consequently, the Department is prepared to approve the admission of George Nokusis to the Qu'Appelle Indian Residential School. You should, therefore, forward the usual application form and certificate of health for our consideration.

When children are once admitted to a residential school, it has not been our practice to transfer them to another school conducted under different religious auspices. However, when the parents insist, the Department will always granted the discharge of the children. You should, therefore, inform the Principal of the File Hills Residential School that we desire Maurice Nokusis - No. 164; and Mildred Nokusis - No. 0190; to be returned to their father at the end of December.

I am in receipt of a communication from Indian Agent Dodds to the effect that he has received instructions from the Department that the above mentioned Pupils of this School are to be returned to their Father at the end of December.

It might interest the Department to know that Nokusis came to my Office during the latter part of July and signed an application for the admission of his Son George to this School, this action was entirely voluntary on his part, I prepared the necessary forms and he signed them willingly, a few weeks after I received an intimation that he wished to have his children transferred to the Qu'Appelle Residential School, I interviewed Nokusis on this subject and he informed me that this was so, when I asked him the reason the only reply he could give was that people were talking, though he could not definitely tell me what they were saying, I took this to be rather a flimsy reason and endeavoured to ascertain if pressure had been brought to bear upon Nokusis to have his children transferred to the Qu'Appelle Residential School, I failed to gather any information regarding this however.

I would point out that the mother of these children is a Protestant and a graduate of this School and still desires that they remain in this School, however I am fully aware that the mothers wishes are not generally considered in matters of this description, I simply mention this so that the Department may see that this desire is not unanimously supported by both parents.

I am very much opposed to these children being transferred to the Qu'Appelle Residential School, the older children Maurice & Mildred have now been in this School nearly six years, the Boy is 15 and the girl 12 and they have become settled in their work, it is going to take some time for them to adjust themselves to another School, I note that the Department are anxious to respect the wishes of the Parents, I think they are rather whims.

I have been informed that a similar case has been brought to the attention of the Department recently, I refer to the case of the Wasna children of the Assiniboine band at Sintaluta, who are now resident in the Brandon Residential School, if I am not mistaken both parents of these children are Roman Catholic and yet their request to have their children transferred to the Qu'Appelle Residential School was not granted, are not these two cases very similar?
I therefore request the Department to re-consider their decision and to order that the children remain at this School until they become of age to be discharged.

Alec Nokis, an Indian on this reserve, is in receipt of a C.E.F. disability pension. The pension which is administered by the agent includes allowances for his wife and children. MEMORANDUM

Mr. MacKenzie,

With reference to your recent memorandum, it is noted that the official of the Auditor General's Department points out that, when the children of Alex. As far as the Department is aware at the present time, none of this man's children are at an Indian residential school. Two of them were attending the File Hills School but were supposed to leave that school at the end of December, 1936.

A note is being made on our file and, in the event of Nokis applying for the admission of his children to any Indian residential school in future, it will be kept in mind that arrangements must be made to have any pension allowed for these children forwarded to the Department rather than to the father.

Fyle References: Re: Douglas SHINGOOSE - Truant Indian Boy, Fyle Hills Indian School, Sask.

In the p.m. of this date Mr. Rhodes (Principal of the above school) telephoned this office and advised that the above mentioned person had run away from school, and he thought possibly that he would go back to the Muscowpetung Indian Reserve, so requested that the police patrol to this reserve with the purpose of locating the truant boy and return him to the school.

Sub-Division: 13-4-37.

This early a.m. the writer patrolled per Pol. auto 1629 to the Muscowpetung Indian Reserve, where Douglas SHINGOOSE was located, at the request of Mr. F. Booth (Indian agent) Douglas SHINGOOSE was conveyed per Pol. auto to this Det'm., where he was handed over to Mr. Rhodes.

78 miles travelled via Pol. auto for the purpose of locating and conveying Truant Indian to this Det'm.

Dear Sir;-

Mr. Booth informs me that Mr. Pratt has obtained the consent of the trustees of South Valley School for his son to attend and that Pratt has guaranteed that he will attend if his request is granted.

(ASSISTANCE TO DEPT. OF INDIAN AFFAIRS)

Headquarters

Sub-Division

Detachment

P.C.R.

First.

In the a.m. of this date I received a telephone message from Mr. Rhodes, Principal of the File Hills Indian School, to the effect that the above named had run away from this school on the previous day and would probably be found on the Pasqua Reserve at his father's home. Mr. Rhodes requested that I apprehend this truant.

1. PASUA was described as 13 years, slim build, 105-110 pounds, wearing blue overalls, brown suit coat, dirty brown cap and leather boots. The boots and clothing would be stamped with the school number "21".

2. I patrolled immediately per Pol. Car Ford Code 1629 to the Pasqua Reserve where I contacted Mr. Platman, Labourer at the Qu'Appelle Agency and questioned him as to whether he had seen PASUA. Patrol then continued to the home of Mr. PASUA. Victor's father, but the boy had not yet arrived there and although several other homes on the reserve at which this boy might be found were visited, we were unable to locate him.

3. Patrol then returned to the detachment, arriving here at approximately 5 p.m. On the return home the police car became stuck in a mud hole, necessitating the hire of a team to pull it out of the hole.

In the p.m. of this date while returning from the Muscowpetung Reserve on other police business I called at John PASUA's home and found Victor there. The boy was then returned to this detachment, and because of the pressing nature of police business I applied the 1629 to Balcarres Detachment and requested that a member of that detachment patrol to Fort Qu'Appelle to escort this truant to the File Hills School. This request was granted and in the late p.m. of this date Cst. Woodward arrived at this detachment and PASUA was handed over to him for escort to the school.

Extra copy of this report attached for the information of Balcarres Detachment.

HANDED OVER TO DEPT. OF INDIAN AFFAIRS.

EXPENSES SHOWN ON P93, period Oct. 1-15.

The C.S., Regina Sub-Div., R.C.M. Police, REGINA.

Enquiries were made around the Village of Balcarres and all places where these boys might be found were carefully checked without results. Sir:

I have your No. 306 and 314-11 A of the 14th instant, with reference to the supplying of milch cows for the Qu'Appelle and File Hills Indian Residential Schools.

In reply I wish to refer you to my communication of the 15th instant. I have also to refer to that portion of your letter of the same file number, in which you state that steps should be taken to remove the tubercular cattle at once and to put the new milch cows in their place as soon as possible. I have to inform you that, in the opinion of the Department, it would be better to arrange for the shipment of the new stock when the barn is completed. The danger of infection in an old barn, where tubercular cattle have been, makes such action advisable.

I shall be pleased to learn from you whether Balcarree is the most suitable point for unloading. It would be necessary for Mr. Agent Deacon to arrange for an officer and boys from each school to take the cattle to their final destinations. Twenty animals will be for the Qu'Appelle School and ten for the File Hills Institution.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 21st inst. with reference to the supplying of milch cows for the Qu'Appelle and File Hills Residential Schools.

You seem to have some concern about the cattle coming in contact with the existing barns at the latter institution. In reply I would say that during the summer months the cattle need not go near the barns at all, but would be pastured and brought to corral at night for milking purposes.

Balcarres would be the most suitable place to unload the cattle, being about nine miles to Lebrat. However, I do not think that ten cows will be sufficient for the File Hills School. I would ask that this be placed at fifteen, and at least 25 be sent to Qu'Appelle. Care should be taken however to see that some of the cows will come in to milk in the late fall, as I do not wish to have all of the cows milking at the same time.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) W.M. Graham.
Indian Commissioner.

I beg to report on the Affairs of this Agency for the quarter period ending June 30th, 1946.

Welfare. The increase effected in garden acreage is due to a great extent to the co-operation given this Office by the Principals of the Qu'Appelle and File Hills Residential Schools. Dear Mr. Rhodes:

I am informed that you are seriously considering discontinuing the cadet corps, concerning which the Department has received rather favourable reports. I am aware that, at the United Church Conference, there was a resolution in this connection, but it is my opinion that the intention was to discourage cadet corps in the public schools in Canada. Residential schools are another proposition, and I believe you will find that a cadet corps at an Indian institution will assist greatly with both the esprit de corps and the discipline. You, of course, are on the ground and know what is best for the File Hills School, but I am of the opinion that you should seriously consider the matter before taking drastic action. Might I have a report from you in this connection.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 19th inst having reference to the disbanding of the Cadet Corps at this School, I beg to advise that I was guided by the resolution passed by the General Conference of the United Church of Canada at London, Ont.

It has been noted for some considerable time that the Boys were not so interested in the work and it was felt that better results would be obtained if we were to disband for the time being and re-organize later when more interest and enthusiasm would be shown by the smaller boys growing up. I may say that at this School there is a certain amount of military discipline maintained at all times, more so than in Public Schools, as there the Boys only gather together for a short period each day, whilst in the Residential Schools they are together all the time and are constantly under supervision.

I cannot quite understand the concern of the District Cadet Officer for M.D.12 at the disbanding of our Corps, he seemed to be quite perturbed when I was talking the matter over with him last August. I explained to him that we had no facilities at this School for carrying on Drills, Musketry etc., the only room of any size in this Building is the Dining room which is 16 feet wide and 75 feet long, to prepare this room for Cadet activities necessitates removing 9 large Dining tables and 18 Benches, quite a lot of exercise in itself, regarding Musketry practice, we have not any place where this can be carried out, true we might take up theory but that becomes very dry and uninteresting in time as I know from practical experience, I have made several requests for an addition to the Building with the view of having a large playroom or Gymnasium in the Basement, this would give us training facilities without the necessity of the Boys having to do such extensive manual labour to prepare the room.

Indian School Opened.

Touchwood, Oct. 15.—The opening of the new Church of England school building at Touchwood took place on Friday last, 15th, in the presence of Mr. Wright, the missionary of Touchwood, and the English settlers.

The building, which has just been finished, is an imposing structure of stone 30 ft. by 40 ft. The interior arrangement is very commodious in all details, containing two large classrooms, a library, a drill room, work room, dairy and store rooms, and separate rooms for the principal, matron and teacher; in short, everything necessary for the best Indian school building in the North-west. We have seen nothing of the quality work that is being done there.

We may congratulate the government represented as we do, on the admirable work done by Mr. Wright, and Rev. Mr. Owens, who have laboured so hard to bring the Indians to the school. They have worked there for many years, on its commencement they were called upon to select also on the contractor, Mr. Chas. Turner, the mason. The progress of the building was watched with interest by the students, writing, spelling, and maps, which were used in the instruction of such schools.

There is an air of homeliness and comfort which seems to pervade the whole school.

As evidence of the interest that is awakened among the Indians, 200 people assembled to take part in the opening exercises of the new Fort Qu'Appelle. In the amiable absence of Mr. Wright, Mr. Owens presided over the service, which was performed by the principal, Mr. Wright, and Rev. Mr. Johnson, of Fort Qu'Appelle, who spoke in a manner which was impressive and was certainly heard by every one of the natives. During the afternoon Mr. Davies, who is an artist of territorial fame took photographs of the missionary and group of the school staff and children run and in the evening Mr. Wright, Mr. Owens, in their well-known hospitable manner invited the Indians to a bounteous supper. After this visitors, particularly those from Fort Qu'Appelle enjoyed an evening, including dancing, so that when the music finally died down it was time to go home. Without referring to the pleasing fact that the new school will benefit the Indians, including several of the chiefs, we may say that the future possibilities of both Christian and heathen which should be realized are great. The future possibilities of this school, and we believe that the same care and support will be given to this the most important mission work of the future, is the real solution to the question of the Indians. It is the only way to bring the Indians into the fold of Christ, and to make them Christians in the land.—(Continued.)

REPORT OF THE INDIAN COMMITTEE.

The Committee on Gordon's Indian School begs to submit its report.

There have been some important changes since the last report. Mr. Mark Williams, the Principal of the School, resigned his position in March of this year, and Mr. Dudley Ward has been appointed as Principal and his wife as Matron. Miss Smalley is assistant Matron. We regret that since his appointment Mr. Ward has had a very serious illness, which has incapacitated him for work. Last year Mr. Cooper was appointed to the teaching staff of the School, and Mr. Murison, the Indian Agent, reports very favorably of his work. There is a full complement of scholars, and no difficulty is anticipated in keeping the numbers up to thirty. A new agreement has been entered into with the Indian Department, by which the School will now receive one hundred dollars grant per capita. Part of the new agreement provides that the male pupils are to be instructed in gardening, farming, the care of stock or such industries as are suitable to their local requirements. Steps will have to be taken by the Committee to carry out this part of the agreement.

It is interesting to note that for the year ending March, 1911, the Principal was able to report a clean bill of health amongst the pupils.

Our best thanks are due to some branches of the Diocesan W. A., and especially to the W. A. in Eastern Canada, for their valuable and generous assistance.

All the outstanding accounts have been paid.

J. P. SARGENT, Chairman.
He has given much valuable help to the principals during his tenure of office as form instructor and has enabled us to grapple successfully with one of our most difficult problems. In my recent visit of inspection to Gordon's Boarding School and discussing various matters with Mr. Atwater, the Principal, I suggested to him that it would be a good thing to bring the number of pupils up to fifty. He has now forty-seven, and he told me that he would be very glad if this could be done as he has the room for them and children available and parents anxious to send them. As you are well aware the increased cost of living in the last two months makes it somewhat difficult to finance the school with the present per capita grant, and naturally the increase in numbers would help us in that direction. Everything is going on very satisfactorily at the school so far as the teaching is concerned and the other work. The farming operations have been very successful and they had a very good crop of cereals and roots.

In company with the Agent and Francis Sears, one of the head men of the Reserve, I went over the land which it is proposed to exchange for the half-section which we own to the west of the school. This exchange has been hanging fire for some time and it would be a great advantage every way if the matter could be put through without further delay.
The Principal is anxious to have a little more land under cultivation. He is a bit circumscribed in that respect at the present time and it would be a great advantage if he had the land which has been surrendered by the Indians in order that he might fence pastures and cultivate a little more of the land immediately round the school.

July 24th, 1918.

Dear Bishop Harding -

I have your communication of July 20th. I shall be pleased to give careful consideration to the representations of the executive committee of your Diocese, regarding Indian affairs, when they come to hand. I am afraid I can hold out little hope, however, of improvements which will entail any extra expenditure. As your Lordship is already aware our appropriation has been very largely reduced, and the strictest economy is necessary. I would not like now to definitely pledge the Department to any expenditure even after the war.

I hope that I shall be in Ottawa when your Lordship visits here in September, and, if so, I shall be glad to see you.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

REPORT OF THE INDIAN COMMITTEE

TO THE MEMBERS OF THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE:

MY LORD AND GENTLEMEN:

On St. John the Baptist's Day, June 24th, an important step in connection with the Indian Work of the Diocese was taken when Mr. W. H. B. Scharpe and Mr. A. J. Laves were ordained in St. Luke's Church, Gordon's Reserve, for work amongst the Indians. There was a large gathering of Clergy, who took part in the service, and the Church was filled with a congregation, Indians and white people from the surrounding district. It was an event to which many in the Diocese had looked forward with much interest and it was felt to be a step in the right direction for the extension of the Church's work amongst the Indians committed to our care.

On the same day a Meeting of the Indian Committee of the Diocese was held at Gordon's Indian School. All the Members of the Committee were present, together with the Principal of the School.

Matters connected with the School and with the Indian Work generally were thoroughly discussed, and as some of these concerned the Department of Indian Affairs it was deemed expedient that the Chairman of the Indian Committee present a report of the meeting to the Executive Committee for their action thereon.

For some time past an effort has been made for a transfer of land belonging to the Synod for an equal amount belonging to the Indians and it was recommended that the East half of section 4-27-17 W2 consisting of 316 acres be exchanged for the N. E. ¼ of section 3 and the N. W. ¼ of section 2 in the same township and range. Mr. Murison, the Indian Agent, has since informed me that he has obtained the sanction of the Indians to this exchange. It was arranged that the Government should retain ten acres of the N. E. of section 3 by metes and bounds, being the site on which Gordon's School stands, together with a road allowance connecting the said ten acres with the nearest government road allowance.
Accommodation having had to be provided for the Rev. A. J. Lawson by the addition of a room to the new wing of the School, this being done with the consent of the Indian Agent, it was decided to ask the Department to defray the cost of the same.

The present method of lighting the school is very unsatisfactory and according to the report of School Inspector McKechnie dangerous. In his official report he makes the following statement: "The danger of fire in the present building, lighted as it is by kerosene lamps and heated by stoves and without an adequate water supply, is very great. It is providential that no tragedy has so far occurred. The Federal authorities should be vigorously informed that a new and up-to-date school building is absolutely necessary for the carrying on of this important work". The Committee felt that the Department should be urged to instal the Delco system of electro-lighting.

The crying need at the present time is a new school building. It was stated by the Indian Agent that at least thirty more children could be brought into the school if the accommodation were provided. The present accommodation is for fifty. The need is for a school to accommodate eighty to one hundred children. There are twenty-three children of school age on the Fishing Lake Reserve and the parents of these children are anxious for a school. There are fifty-four children at Nut Mountain Reserve but the parents are against education for their children. The Committee feel that the children from Day Star School should be brought to Gordon's at the age of fourteen. The advantage of a boarding school over a day school is that from the day school children can be discharged from the age of fourteen whilst at a boarding school they can be retained until the age of eighteen.

A Cottage Hospital is another great need for the children during illness and for necessitous cases from the Reserve and particularly maternity cases. Already $142.25 have been spent this year for a pupil having to be taken to a hospital at Saskatoon. Under present conditions the Matron has to give up her room for any case requiring isolation and has herself to undertake the nursing. The Department should be asked to make some provision along the lines suggested.
The question of providing a school at Fishing Lake was discussed by the Committee and after hearing what the Indian Agent had to say it was felt that the best solution was the providing of a larger school at Gordon's Reserve and bringing the children from Fishing Lake to the latter place. Further information, however, on the subject has led to a different conclusion and I now feel that it is important that we should have a school at Fishing Lake. The urgency of the need is all the more evident when the fact is known that constantly children have to be refused admission to Gordon's for lack of room. The confidence of the Indians in the school is very great and makes it all the more incumbent upon the Church to do all in Her power to further the interests of the school and through the Executive Committee to bring these facts before the Department of Indian Affairs, praying them to take immediate steps to provide accommodation for the children of school age on these Reserves.

In view of the loss of such Indian Schools as Elkhorn, Middlechurch, Battleford, Calgary, to the Church of England, the Committee should view with alarm the possibility of the effective work of Gordon's Indian School being retarded through lack of proper provision by the Department, and in asking on behalf of the Indian Committee for the adoption of this Report, I would respectfully request the Executive Committee through the Bishop of the Diocese to bring these facts before the Department of Indian Affairs with a view to steps being taken for the improvement of existing conditions.

All of which is respectfully submitted,

Chairman of the Indian Committee.

Regina, Saskatchewan, July 16, 1918.

Sir,

I beg to report that on Sunday last a Pupil of the Gordon Boarding School named Percy Crane, aged about seventeen years, struck the Principal over the head with a piece of board partially stunning him; he then jumped upon him and tried to hold him down. Mr. Atwater then tried to take the boy to the Dormitory, but he was not able to do so and with the help of his Assistant he took him to the Office and sent for Alec Geddes to whom he gave him in charge and laid an information against the boy for assault.

I sent the boy to Regina Goal for one month as there is no Reformatory in the Province that I know of. This seemed a hard thing to do, but the boy had to be punished as an example to the others. Expulsion from the School under the circumstances would have been a reward rather than a punishment and would have been a suggestion to others who wanted to leave school to try a similar course.

I feel that it would have been better if the Principal had administered punishment himself with what assistance he could get.

CHURCH AND STATE AND THE INDIAN

While on a vacation in Northern Saskatchewan, was the privilege of the writer to visit two Indian Reserves, namely, Gordon Reserve and Day Star Reserve. The first named is what is called a Christian settlement, while Day Star Reserve remains pagan and is still held in the dark by superstition and heathenism.

Both Reserves come under the jurisdiction of the Church of England, but they are also under the Diocese of Qu'Appelle. This being the case, it was with peculiar interest that the writer accepted an invitation to visit the Reserves. I wish I could tell my readers that Gordon Reserve possesses a boarding school for Indians, but it is not so. It is a normal school in Brandon. Such is not the case. He never saw a more dilapidated and insanitary building. The roof is low pitched and very badly ventilated—if at all. Conveniences here are none; sleeping apartments with no air, kitchens and dining-hall are underground, and conditions here are abominable—fit breeding places for disease. Floors and walls are covered with everything. In one dormitory containing some twenty beds, but which has only been occupied for three weeks, there is a pump by which rain water is brought into the room for washing purposes from an old tank. A damp and unhealthy atmosphere. The State and Church are content that these things should remain so. It is disgusting! It is impossible to remain longer, and hurriedly sought the pure air of the rolling prairie; but not before we had heard the story of the Indians whose white faces clearly show the effects of such insanitary and dismal accommodation.

The only saving grace about the place is the very real sacrifice being made by the Rev. Mr. Atwater and his wife, who are working among their lives in an endeavor to educate and Christianize the boys and girls of the Reserve. These servants of God share the same hard work and dangers with the brown-skinned charges. Apparently Bishop Harding is powerless to remedy these disgraceful conditions, and the State Department of Ojibwa is too deaf and too blind to hear the pleas and see the needs of these poor Indians.

The good Bishop admits that conditions at Gordon School have caused him much anxiety during the past few years. Plans for new schools, we are told, have been drawn and furnished the Indian Committee—but this story he has been told for years past and cannot be true.

I shall never forget my visit to Day Star Reserve. An Overland stage passed through the rolling trails through the huge settlement, which for natural beauty beggars description. The huts, huts of the horrid, dirty Indians, from the open sheds and lairs. We were told these were pure pagans and all efforts to Christianize them had proven fruitless. Mrs. Turner, a missionary educated, and trained medical missionary from England, and her husband have been sent to help Bishop Harding and other American missionary bishops. Their task is a difficult one, and as yet little results are seen to encourage them. They have been here for seven months and it has been impossible to get the natives together for any kind of service. The work among the children attending the attendance day school is also slow and sadly disappointing. Mr. Turner tells us that the Indians do not improve in the religious sense as he has cultivated than anything else. They will come to his little place and sit for hours smoking their pipes and talking or however mumbling to themselves the while. Here the Indians live in all their primitive condition. Shacks are very rambunctious. The influence started many of them to the "happy hunting ground," one woman alone killing her children and burying them in the chil- dren's plot. Miss Turner informs us that the Indian very quickly gives himself up to death. When sick, he says to himself, "I am going to die." He does because he thinks he must die. He will squat on the floor of his tent, put his hands around his knees, drop his head, and say, "I am going to die." He may—it may be for weeks—and in this posture he is buried.

Here again is the question of Church and State. Why? Let us hope that as a result of the American Forward Movement, the Indian Mission will be strengthened and our country should vig- orously "bombard" the Indian Department with de- mands for better equipment and more facilities in which to carry on mission work and education work among the Indians on Gordon and Day Star Reserves.

Sir,

The Lord Bishop of Qu'Appelle sent Archdeacon Knowles up last week to investigate the cause of the truancy of pupils of Gordon's School during the past summer, the alleged cause being the attitude of my engineer, Mr. Handley, towards the boys.

As twice as many girls as boys ran away, even small girls seven years of age, with whom Mr. Handley has nothing to do, a prima facie case against him could scarcely be considered.

Mr. Inspector Christianson was asked by me to come to the school and investigate matters, and I invited the parents of the children here to make their complaints, instead of running to the Agency with them. The complaint they had to make against Handley was, that he had a rough way of speaking to the boys, but the boys themselves, who had run away, made no complaint against Handley. They gave various reasons for truancy. Two of them ran away because they did not like picking up potatoes after the potato digger, others, that they were not paid for doing work outside; another that he had to cut some wood two or three times.

At the close of the investigation, Mr. Christianson, in speaking to the children assembled in the schoolroom with members of the Staff, stated that although he had been informed by some of the people that Mr. Handley's attitude to the children had been the cause of their
truaney, he had found no proof that such was the case.

Two of the parents were more disposed to make complaints against me, one, that I made the children take their meals lying on the floor, with their hands tied behind their backs, another, that I was spiteful to children whose parents I did not like, but when asked to specify cases, had only heard it.

The Indians always have complaints galore about Indian Agents, and about each other, which they would weary me with if I had patience to listen to them, or thought it wise to do so.

I have always aimed at a strict line of duty, rather than pleasing the people, which, everywhere is impossible.

The only objection to Mr. Handley is that his temper gets the better of him at times, as for instance when, as on two occasions, boys have gone to the engine room and broken the wire connecting the magneto with the spark plug, or stolen tarred tape off the electric wire; but he merely talks forcibly, and never on any occasion has used any objectionable language.

The doctor, who is the Department's Medical Health Officer, secured Handley's services for me three years ago, and it is his opinion that life in the trenches is responsible for his erratic temper, which, however, affects the Staff more than it does the pupils.

He is a most useful man and is always ready to do any kind of work for the school or for the good of the pupils.

He now understands the heating and lighting system and manages the plumbing also, and his services could not be replaced at the salary he
is getting, viz. $50 a month.

I am surprised that his dismissal should have been recommended on account of the boys, as the investigation showed that they had no complaint against him, and as to the parents, the substance of their objections was his rough way of speaking. They alleged more substantial grievances against me, but these existed only in their own imaginations.

As I told them afterwards, I invited them to make real complaints, if they had any, not to make false statements.

Report re Gordon's School - Dec. 31st, 1923.

Mr. Bishop,

In accordance with your Lordship's instructions I visited Gordon's School on Saturday Evening Dec. 29th, and remained until the Sunday afternoon.

The Rev. Atwater seemed in very good spirits and assisted me in every possible way in regard to obtaining information regarding the questions of Truancy and the trouble about Mr. Handly.

With regard to Truancy I found that, as stated by the Department, there had been a number of cases since May 1923. It is most difficult for me to report upon each occurrence as the school does not keep a diary, and it would be necessary to obtain information from the Police reports.

Truancy has been a frequent occurrence in many Indian Boarding Schools for some time past, and perhaps the trouble at Gordon's has been accentuated by the fact that until this Summer there had very few cases as compared with other schools. Another factor which may have accentuated the matter may be that in some other schools the culprits may be left for several days before the Police are notified—during which time many may return or be brought back by parents or others.

Truancy to some extent is a natural offence in that Indian children are apt to take advantage of a sudden impulse for adventure, or to see their parents. Also there appear to have been certain ringleaders who have dared the others to follow them. In every case reported to me it was the staff of the school which had taken the initiative in seeking the truants, and in particular Mr. John Handly, using his own car, had immediately sought for them. On some occasions he was accompanied by the Police.

Mr. Rhodes of the File Hill School called on the Rev. Atwater and spoke of his difficulties in regard to runaways. Archdeacon McKay also visited Gordon's and spoke of his troubles in this regard. Muscowikans and Lebret have also had similar difficulties.

The punishment for this offence is now to be increased by six months the term of attendance at the school, which in the case of the older pupils it is expected will have a salutary effect. There have been no cases during the last month.

Re John Handly:- I spent considerable time with the Rev. Atwater, Miss Atwater and Miss McLeish regarding the charges made by the Department that "he is certainly not the stamp of man that should be employed in an Indian Boarding School— he is officious and domineering". As far as I could find, Handly seems to have been an energetic and faithful servant. Working on the comparatively small salary of $50 per month and board he has been used in the capacity of the Principal's right-hand.

Enlisting in the 26th Batt from Regina in 1915 he served in the Great War and rose to the position of Sergeant. He was at Mons on Nov. 11th, 1918 and served in Germany till July 1919. He came to Gordon's in July 1921. Of a quick temper and rather nervous disposition, perhaps due to his service, he must be blamed for many acts of impatience, but in most cases under some provocation.

The condition of affairs at the School has been that Handly has occupied a place above his position as regards education, but this cannot be said to be his fault. In many ways the staff has depended upon him, until it has become the habit to go to him rather than to the Principal.

In the end of November, after the investigation held by Inspector Christianson, the Principal gave him a month's notice. The man was terribly upset and went away weeping, blaming himself for his hasty temper and foolishness. He returned to the Principal apologizing, and stating his whole heart was in the work of the school, asked to be given another chance. Dr. Phillips commenting on the situation said "If Handly goes the Rev. Atwater will not be able to continue. The Principal asked that Handly be kept on until say the end of June.

He started questioning Daniels concerning why he had run away from the school, the boy never answered him, then he told the boy to take the smile off his face or that he would take it off for him, and he drew his arm back in a threatening manner as if he was going to strike the boy. Then I butted in and asked him if he was one of the staff, meaning the teaching staff and he answered yes, so I said no more at the time not knowing the system that they used at the school for handling the boys. Shortly afterwards Rev. A.W. Atwater, the Principal, came in the office, and I noticed that this man's manner changed. Later the principal questioned the boys in a kind way, in a different manner to what this other man had done. I was going to speak to the Principal concerning this matter but changed my mind thinking that he was one of the teachers. I did not like his manner as it was nothing else but bullying the boys, and at the time I considered that the boys were still in my charge until such time as I had handed them over to the Principal, and I might say that I didn't have the least bit of trouble with any of the boys all the time that I had them, which was since the previous night, and I didn't see any reason why he started on Daniels as he did. Dear Mr. Scott:-

I beg to inform you that the matter of increasing the pupilage at the Gordon Residential School is one that I think the Department should give consideration to without delay.

While this school has not got the prescribed air space of 500 cubic ft. per pupil, it has sufficient air space to meet the requirements of the Health Department of the Province of Saskatchewan. I may say I took this matter up with the Deputy Minister of Health, and he agreed with me that 400 cubic ft. was quite ample, in fact less if proper attention was given to ventilation, such as keeping the windows open, etc. I venture to say there are very few white boarding schools in this Province, or in any other province of the West that provide 500 cubic ft. of air per pupil; certainly the hotels or public places that are under Government control do not.

Now the question is simply this; we have accommodation here for more children than the school is paid a grant for; the school authorities are undertaking to give these children an education, and I may say that they are not going out through the country to hunt for these children; they are brought to the school and they have simply taken them in. It seems to me the Department would be doing the best thing in paying a grant for the children thus brought in, in order that we may make use of all the space available in the schools which are now in existence, before undertaking to build any more.

All that this school is asking for is a grant for 115 pupils. They are now receiving a grant for 100.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

Since my appointment in June, 1926 to the Principalship of the above school I have gone very carefully into everything and, while I think there has been a little progress made, I am very much handicapped for lack of funds.

As you are well aware, the old school was situated in the middle of a half section of land, N.W. of 2 and N.E. of 27-17 West 2nd Meridian, owned by the Synod of the Diocese of Qu'Appelle.

The late Canon Atwater was unable to clear much of this land and consequently had to buy many things which, under ordinary circumstances, the farm should produce.

There are only 57 acres cleared on this half section. The new school, round which there are only three acres of open land, is one and one half miles distant from our other fields and my desire is to link up the two and have a farm on which we can grow all our own feed and so move a step nearer self-support. Last summer and fall we cleared and plowed about four acres.

You can well understand that clearing will be a very slow process but I intend doing as much as possible each year and so gradually increase our acreage. Meanwhile I have to buy all my hay, and also some oats, as we must summerfallow a certain number of acres each year.

REPORT
re: Complaint of Rev. Percival - Principal,
GORDON INDIAN SCHOOL / Punnichy, Sask.

On the A.M. of the 16th instant, a phone call was received from the Principal, Gordon Indian School, requesting that I come at once to the school, as he wished the assistance of the Police.

I immediately patrolled with livery to Gordon Indian School, situated on Co-op Indian Reserve, and on arrival at the school, interviewed the Rev. Percival; and he informed me that an attempt had been made the night previous, by some person or parties unknown, to gain entrance to the school, and that a hasp and padlock which he had placed on the boys dormitory door on the afternoon of the 15th instant had been cut; and he was of the opinion, that it had been done with the object in view, that the senior boys could make effect a breakaway, and attend a dance that was being held on the reserve that night (15th). The hasp and lock was on the door leading to the fire escape, and was on the outside. The hasp was found broken about 9-00 P.M.

About 11-00 P.M., Rev. Percival placed a Member of the staff outside to watch the building, armed with a shot-gun and instructions that if anyone was seen approaching the building from the outside, he was to halt them and fire a shot into the air (which would be a signal to the staff inside). All was well until about 11-30 P.M., when Mr. Snowden, outside guard, noticed three faces at the window of the boys dormitory and the one of the screens of the window was being taken off; at the same time, he noticed five men approaching from the direction of the school stables, and as he was afraid they would detect him, he fired two shots into the air, the men from the direction of the stables disappeared into know the bushes, the screen window was replaced on the dormitory, and when the dormitory was checked a few minutes after the shot, all appeared to be quiet and no one was absent from the dormitory.

I examined the door leading onto the fire escape, and found the hasp had been cut, apparently by a chisel or other sharp instrument, and the lock was still hanging in the staple. The door is fastened with a Yale night latch; this would not unlock with the key, as some obstructions appeared in the lock.

With this information, I discussed the situation with Rev. Percival, and he agreed that it might be well to leave the matter for another day, and he would endeavor to secure information from the school-children, and I arranged that I would come to the school the following morning, with the Indian Agent and we would have a thorough investigation; I then returned to detachment.
On the A.M. of the 16th instant, accompanied by Mr. Moore, Indian Agent, I patrolled to Gordon School, and assisted by Mr. Moore, Indian Agent, Rev. Percival, Principal of Gordon School. I questioned all the senior boys of the school, but no light whatever could be learned as to who cut the hemp the night previous, or who was implicated in the taking off of the screen the night previous, but during the inquiry, I learned that one Billy Brittain, school-boy was in the habit of picking various locks with a wire, and he had on a number of occasions picked the Yale lock of the dormitory door leading to the fire escape; and by this means, a couple of the senior boys had on two occasions left the school during the night, returning early and had not been missed.

Billy Brittain when questioned at first denied everything, claiming he had never at any time opened any locks, but when faced with one of the other boys, admitted that he was the one that had been picking the locks around the school, and when this admission was obtained, the Principal and Rev. Percival stated that he would have this boy severely punished for his actions, as well as the two boys who had left the school during the night, but all the boys were emphatic in their denial that they were not, or did not know of any party that had cut the hemp; however, further inquiries will be made from time to time, and if information of a reliable source can be obtained, a further investigation will be made, and report submitted in due course.

As regards the five men seen approaching from the stables, I have been unable to find out who they might have been, but no doubt, it was some Indians who were endeavoring to assist the school boys in making an escape from the school; and the Principal of the School will endeavor to find out, if possible, who they may have been, and if successful, report accordingly.

Dear Dr. Scott,

The Ven. Archdeacon Knowles, Chairman
of our Indian Committee, and the Rev. M.C.T.
Percivall, Principal of Gordon's Indian Residential
School, have being considering with me the real
need for an increase in the per capita grant which
now stands at $155.00 per annum.

I have just returned from a visitation
at Gordon's, Fishing Lake and Day Star's Schools
and have considered carefully in particular with
the Principal and Chairman of our Indian Committee
the present position and needs of Gordon's School.
We feel we must ask the Department to increase the
per capita grant to $170.00 per annum per pupil for
the following reasons:

1. That the School is now receiving a minimum of
   100 pupils. The number on the roll at present
   is 106. This necessitates an increase in the staff.
2. It is necessary to appoint a resident Farm Instructor for work all the year round in order to increase the instruction of the boys in agriculture and oversee their practical work in the field and garden. This will mean both an additional cost and also much additional to the instruction given in the School.

3. We find the assistance we have previously received from the Dominion Woman's Auxiliary may be seriously decreased in 1929.

4. An increased amount must also be expended by the School in connection with the clothing of the Children, particularly the boys.

5. We wish to call the Departments attention to the fact that the School is situated 7½ miles South of the town of Punnichy. The annual consumption of coal is 1400 to 1450 tons per annum, 15 tons of flour, besides groceries gasoline, oil and other supplied. This requires daily teaming from the Town to the School and is an expensive item on the School account.

6. We notice also the per capita grant to other Schools in the vicinity is considerably larger than the per capita grant to Gordon's.
For these reasons I feel we may justly ask the Department of Indian Affairs to increase the per capita grant to Gordon's School by $15.00 for each pupil for the year.

I am,

Very sincerely yours,

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK. Sept. 29th, 1928.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that, as per your instructions, in company with the Venerable Archdeacon Knowles, I visited the Gordon's Indian Residential School on the 27th and 28th.

During the present month there have been 14 cases of truancy at the school. The children have all been brought back to the school with the exception of one boy who is somewhere around Saskatoon. I looked into this matter as thoroughly as possible and the conclusion I came to was that the children really had no reason for doing this, as I do not think they are being mistreated in any way. In my opinion it is caused by lack of proper supervision; there has been no Farming Instructor there during the summer and no boys' supervisor. As a consequence, with bluffs all around the school, the children have every opportunity of getting out of sight of the school in a short time. The reason some of the boys gave for their misconduct was that they wanted to get out and make some money during the harvest and threshing. I might, however, say that there is a boys' supervisor at the school now who was taken on a few days ago so a closer watch is being kept over the boys.

With regard to the interior of the school, I went all over this and have no fault to find. Everything is in order.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
thing was in fairly good shape, both up and downstairs. Their engine and boiler rooms were in splendid shape too - everything was tidy and in order, but it is in the outside management where a decided change will have to take place. I will just outline a few of the things that have happened there.

When the Rev. Mr. Percivall took charge of the school in April, he found that the Farming Instructor was a drunkard and evidently a morally bad character, not only drinking himself, but giving liquor to the boys. He was given 30 days notice by the Rev. Mr. Percivall, but was there to put in the crop etc. It is now alleged by the Principal that the Farming Instructor dipped the seed potatoes in formalin so that they would not grow. As a consequence 6 acres of potatoes only yielded approximately 100 bushels and it will be necessary for the school to purchase about 700 bushels of potatoes. The smaller seeds, such as carrots, turnips etc., were planted 9" deep so that they would not grow. The result is that they have very few vegetables. Since this man was discharged they have had no Farming Instructor at all, with the exception of the Indian who is working there.

The outbuildings are gradually going to pieces - a board gets knocked off, leaving a hole, and it is not long before the boys tear off another board; window panes are broken and not replaced; the yard between the stable and the school is littered with sticks, etc., and fences need repairing. The yard around the farmer's cottage, which was finished two or three weeks ago, is still littered with chips and boards etc.

No new land
No new land has been broken up and the school is only farming 65 acres which has got so badly polluted with weeds that it would not raise a crop. Mr. Percival took the only course with the farming this spring that he could and put in rye and oats mixed. He cut this crop green and is using it for feed. There is 75 acres of land which can be broken up without doing any brushing at all, but one year goes by after another without any effort being made to break this land. I would also point out that absolutely no effort has been made, since the school was built, to beautify the grounds.

I pointed these matters out to the Ven. Archdeacon Knowles and the Rev. Principal, and the words I used to the Principal were these - "If I were here and it was necessary, I would close up the senior school room for several days so as to enable me to use all the boys to get the grounds cleaned up." The remark made by the Principal was, "I took away 175 loads of rubbish from around the school after I arrived here last spring".

In conclusion, I might say that the outside work at this school could not be worse. There is no supervision there at all and the school is not meeting the object for which it was established. I was pleased to note and have always known that the girls in the school get a good training. This is due to the work of the two Miss Atwaters. They are splendid women and have been there a long time and are efficient in their work. The boys are supposed to receive a training in farming.
in farming and stock raising, etc., but this they are not getting, and the Department should insist on a man being placed in charge of the outside work who is capable of performing his duties.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christiansen,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
