The Reverend,
Rural Dean Stanford,
Regina, Sask.

My dear Rural Dean,

After long and careful consideration with the Chairman of the Diocese Indian Committee, the Indian Department, and the Indian Commissioner, and your own desire to give yourself to Indian Work as Principal of Gordon's Indian Residential School, I have both pleasure and confidence in asking you to accept and discharge the duties attached to the Principalship of that Institution as from Monday, November 26th, next, when I shall hope formally to introduce you to the Staff, and install you in your Office.

While doing this, I feel it will be helpful to you if I notice certain things the Indian Commissioner, the Chairman of the Indian Committee, and the Bishop himself have had in mind for some time.

First: it has been evident that there is a pressing need for a Vice Principal, a man upon whom the Principal could rely, and who could perform his duties when the Principal is absent. The Vice Principal might be a man in Holy Orders, or a capable Layman. If a clergyman filled that position it might be possible for him to act as Curate-in-Charge of Punished Mission. It is proposed to initiate such an arrangement the Bishop has approved a grant at the rate of $500.00 a year, and an increase of the Principal's Stipend from $900.00 as it is now to $1000.00 on condition of his devoting his energies to the Indians and their Children in the School and on the Indian Reserve.

Second; the Committee and the Indian Commissioner have frequently stressed the need of a competent farm instructor to have charge of the farm, the garden, and all outdoor work with the distinct approval and support of the Principal. This they feel would provide for the increase of outdoor work and activities for the boys. Such an appointment, the Committee feels, would be a great help to the Principal, and considerably increase the production of vegetables.
and grain for the benefit of the School. Mr. W. Graham, the Indian Commissioner will be glad to assist you in procuring such an officer, while the Department has already provided a comfortable house for himself and family. A decided development of the boys' interests in Agriculture, gardening, and outdoor sports will mean much for them and the School.

The Committee feels considerable care should be exercised in emphasizing the importance of the position of the Head Matron within the Institution, and among the Staff. Seeing a house has been provided by the Department for the Principal and his family the Principal's Wife will not now feel she holds a responsible position on the Staff of the School, or than any other woman required of her more than is acquired of the wife of a Parish Priest; such interest and assistance as she may be able, as the wife of a clergyman, to give her husband. Naturally, the wife will expect all the regard and esteem she would enjoy in a Parish, but the Committee feel she should be spared the responsibility that belongs to the Office of Matron or a member of the Staff.

The School, as you know, is one of the most important institutions in the Diocese, and has for many years called forth the greatest interest of the Church, and the headmaid of the Church, the Queen's Auxiliary. The Principal will naturally work in the closest association with the Indian Department, and will need to remember that it is important that the Department's requirements are met in every particular. The Department has shown itself ready at all times in the past to support the Church in her Indian work, and I feel that both the Diocese and the Principal of the School may rely upon its whole hearted support in the future.

The Indian Committee feels the financial arrangements at the School will at all times demand the strictest care and attention from the Principal, as otherwise it will be easy for large debts to accumulate. Indeed, I feel the Principal will need to see that the financial arrangements are under his direct jurisdiction and oversight.

Your appointment to this position gives us much confidence because you have felt called to undertake work in one of the widest spheres of influence, and certainly prayer shall be made that you may be given health and grace to do the Institution what the Church and the Department wish it to be. The affairs of the School necessarily will be largely left in your hands under the direction of the Venerable Archdeacon Knowles, the Chairman of the Diocesan Indian Committee.

In making the appointment I wish to thank you for long and valuable assistance given me as Rural Dean of Regina, and as Chairman of our Diocesan Sunday School Committee. I shall miss your ready help and loyal support in these offices, but I shall gladly spare you further great work upon which we are now entering, and hope you will still be able to give your brethren the benefit of sympathy and experience when the duties upon which you will shortly enter permit you to do so.

Believe me, my dear Mr. Stanford,

Most sincerely yours,

D REGINA, SASK., Oct. 26th, 1928

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your 121-1-1, of the 13th instant, with reference to Inspector Christianson's report on the Gordon Indian Residential School.

In accordance with your wishes I have undertaken to give special assistance in the matter of supervision, and I drove out to this school and back yesterday, a distance of 200 miles, with a view of ascertaining at first hand just how matters stood. I was surprised on my arrival to find that no less than 17 of the boys, pupils of the school, had deserted during the week, and at the time of my visit, ten of them were still at large. I am in receipt of a letter this morning from a party at Saskatoon, asking what is the matter at the school. I have no idea where the balance of the boys are, but I am having the Police notified at all points throughout the province. Conditions at this school really could not be worse, and it shows that the Principal is absolutely incompetent to manage an institution of this kind. I found the water down pipes at every corner of the building were battered flat, so that the water could only leak through. Where the pipes leave the building I found holes deep enough to bury a couple of washtubs, and the water had all summer been running in against the foundation, showing absolute neglect. The new stables which we built there a short time ago I found with the doors off the hinges and smashed up, and nearly all the glass broken. The manure carriers which were installed have disappeared. They have been deliberately torn down and apparently lost. The whole picture presented was one of neglect and destruction, and the Principal has completely lost control of the staff. In trying to get at the reason for these wholesale desertions the

-Principal-

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Principal told me that this was to be expected, in view of the manner in which the Department and the Agent handled the case of one of the boys, a lad of 16, who recently deserted from the school. When I heard that this boy was giving trouble I instructed that he be taken at once to Elkhorn. This was done, but he was only there a short time when he deserted and came back to Gordon's, and instead of having him sent back to Elkhorn, or to some other Anglican School at a distance, the Department authorized that he be discharged. Of course, this was a victory for the boy, and the discipline at the school, instead of improving, was made much worse, and I agree with the Principal in this that the boy should not have been discharged. He has been visiting the school two or three times a week, and the other boys, seeing what this boy did, will naturally follow his example, hoping that they will receive the same treatment and be discharged. I find fault with the Agent for recommending this. He knew perfectly well that had he called me up I would have insisted on the boy returning to Elkhorn. He also knew that it was on my instructions he was sent to Elkhorn in the first place. Mr. Moore did not report these desertions until he was forced to do so. He must share some of the responsibility for the conditions at the school, as he is in charge of the agency in which it is situated. My files show that he has never reported anything. Now, no matter what management this school is under it cannot function properly with this kind of supervision from the Agent, and I think you will agree with me that a mistake was made in handling this case of truancy in this way. However, I am not attributing all the difficulty we are having to this. The management is lax.

His Lordship was in to see me last week, and he has made another appointment to this post. The man who has been chosen has absolutely no knowledge of agriculture and I do not know what the result will be, and have told the Bishop so. The Church authorities are going to allow me to appoint a man as Farming Instructor, who will be given more responsibility than any former Instructor had in connection with the management of the outside affairs at the school. The Bishop insists on having a clergyman in charge, which, to my mind is a mistake. I have no doubt there are clergymen who are capable of handling a job of this kind, but this is the fourth appointment at the Gordon School since Mr. Atwater died, and three of them have been absolute failures.

Yours very truly,

Wm. Graham
Indian Commissioner.

PROBES CAUSE
40 Indian Children Will Be Accommodated at Elkhorn, Manitoba, School
OTHERS WILL STAY IN PUNNICHY AREA
106 Children Safe After $200,000 Fire at Gordon Indian School

Forty Indian children attending the Gordon Indian School at Punnichy, which was razed to the ground by fire Friday, will be taken to the new Gordon Indian School at Elkhorn, Manitoba. Rev. Mr. Elery, principal of the Elkhorn school, was in Regina this morning on his way North.

Of the remaining children, some are being housed temporarily in the Gordon, Poorman and Daystar reserves and some will be housed in the old Gordon school, now served as the former Gordon's Indian School before the new building was erected.

Investigative Cause
S. S. Moore, Indian agent at Punnichy, is at the scene the fire Friday investigating the cause. The school, which is situated about seven miles southeast of Punnichy, was totally destroyed by the fire which broke out shortly after 3 o'clock Friday afternoon. The loss estimated at $200,000.

None of the 106 Indian children attending the school, nor the staff of ten, were injured.

The fire was discovered near the boy's dormitory by the section of the school Miss Atwater, the matron, who first called the firemen and to give the alarm.

Property Saved
The children's clothing and bedding were saved by the older children, the staff and helpers. After the children had marched to safety, Rev. Frederic Stanford, previously stationed temporarily went from the rectoryship of St. Peter's Anglican Church, in charge, saved the furniture of the chapel, chapel equipment and church records.

Boys and Girls
Under the supervision of two of the teachers, a number of the older boys and girls assisted in salvaging what they could from their section of the school and engaged in similar work in the girls' section of the building.

In the meantime the other children were in the old stone building which was used as a gymnasium and auditorium. It was here the entire school was gathered when the little roll call was made to see that all were accounted for. The 6 o'clock meal was served there.

Gordon's Indian School, which was conducted under the Anglican church, was one of the oldest Anglican missions in Canada. The building was owned by the Federal Government. Classes were held there and conducted there. In 1921 the old stone building in use was replaced by a modern brick-veneer structure with water and electricity installed. The school was erected by Smith Bros. and Wilson, Regina.

A number of townsmen from Punnichy went by car to the scene of the fire to see what they heard of it and assisted with the work of salvaging.

No decision has yet been made concerning the erection of a new school.
Dear Mr. Scott:-

Mr. Eley left Punnichy this morning at 3 o'clock for Elkhorn, taking with him forty children from the Gordon's school. It will be necessary for him to stop over at a place called Nokomis from 4 a.m. until 10 a.m. and then take a train for Elkhorn, which will arrive there at nine o'clock tonight. I have arranged with the C.N.R. to put a heated car on the train passing through Punnichy and to have a heated car on from Nokomis to Elkhorn for their accommodation. I have also arranged to have the children fed at Nokomis this morning and a supply of food put on the train taking them from Nokomis to Elkhorn.

These children will take with them a certain amount of quilts and blankets, but the mattresses were not fit to move, being very old, and the beds were all destroyed, so I am purchasing new beds and mattresses to accommodate them at Elkhorn; and if any additional members of staff are required they will be taken over from the Gordon School.

We still have sixty children to provide for on the reserve, some of them in homes that are not very good, and until the question of re-building—

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
re-building is settled I am afraid we will have to take some of them into the File Hills School. I do not think there would be any objection on the part of the Church authorities to this move. If I find that these children cannot be handled at home I intend sending them to File Hills but before doing so I would acquaint the Church authorities with the circumstances and get their approval.

I expect Mr. Moore's report on his investigation as to the cause of the fire very soon, but in conversation over the phone I gathered that there was little hope of being able to say exactly what the cause was - probably a match or cigarette thrown into the wall.

Some of the children are housed in a lean-to annex which was next to the school, where the staff hope to carry on class-room work for the time being. I do not know whether this will be a success or not, as I fear the building is not fit for that sort of work. The work of looking after the stock and farming arrangements is being carried on by the staff that remains at the school.

Mr. Swan, who was the building inspector when this school was erected, and who was in my office yesterday was an eye witness of the fire, and from what I can gather it was a long time before the building burst out in flames. Smoke was seen coming from under the floors and they started chopping holes here and there but were unable to get to the main body of the fire, which spread so much that it soon got between the studs and ran up past the first and second floors.

It may be necessary for me to grant some assistance to these parents who have had their children sent home. However, this will be inquired into and handled in the best way possible.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have your 512-11B of the 5th instant, with reference to the arrangements you are making for the pupils of the Gordon's Indian Residential School. Care should be taken at Elkhorn that there is plenty of air space in the dormitories. Your action in purchasing extra beds is approved. If there is any other equipment at Gordon's, that was saved from fire, which should be forwarded with these pupils to Elkhorn, you should see that the necessary action is taken.

If any more of the former pupils at Gordon's have no proper home on the reserve, we should consider enrolling them at the Onion Lake C. E. School. According to the last return, there is room here for approximately 15. None of the children should be sent to File Hills without the full concurrence of the church authorities.

I note that some of the children are being accommodated in an annex and that the staff hope to carry on classroom work in the buildings that remain after the fire. You might discuss this with the church authorities and see that proper arrangements are made for whatever activity you consider possible under the circumstances.

Miss IVY BUTCHER, Assistant Sewing Matron.

When the alarm sounded I was working in the sewing-room. Three girl pupils were with me. We went out to the hall and up to the senior class-room and saw smoke coming up through the floor by the radiator. Mr Sinclair was stooping down over where the smoke was. I grabbed an extinguisher from the guest-room opposite the staff sitting-room and took it to the radiator by the stairs leading down to the boys' play-room and used it on the place where I saw smoke coming through. Miss Atwater and I took the fire hose off the bracket on the main floor and ran it out towards the classroom, playing the water at the same time that I played water on the classroom floor. We were then relieved by the men and I went up to the girls dormitory with the girls and Mrs Collins, and threw bedding etc out of the windows.

Signed,

Ivy Butcher.

Mr. E.A. HOLYCOK, Farming Instructor.

On Friday afternoon last (February 1st, 1929), Mr Stanford and myself drove over to the Old School right after dinner, and were returning when we were told that the school was on fire. Driving up to the school I saw smoke coming from the playrooms on the south side. I went right into the senior boys' playroom and saw flames in the ceiling near the radiator pipes. I then put an extra length on the fire hose and played on the fire there. After getting this out someone called that flames were showing on the main floor in the candy-room. A bucket brigade played on this and I also placed hose on it and put it out. Then a call came from the junior playground where the fire was burning between the ceiling and floor of the bale-room. I then was called to the senior boys lavatory where fire was raging near the register. Whilst there, the partition between the two lavatories collapsed. I then went to the bale-room which was thick with smoke and played the hose there, but the smoke was too thick so I took the hose outside and played through the bale-room window. The whole room suddenly burst into flames which were uncontrollable. I then went to the senior classroom and played on it until forced out by smoke, and then to the junior classroom until the fire drove me out. I then turned to salvaging as much as possible from the building. As to the cause, possibly a short-circuit; if, as is rumoured, a blow-torch had been used to thaw out water pipes this may have been the origin.

Signed,

E.A. Holycook.
Miss. ATWATER. Matron.

The first intimation I had that the school was on fire was when the alarm rang. Mr Sinclair, Miss Lou Atwater and myself got the children from the school in good order and handed them over to Mr Williams, the boys' supervisor. Mr Sinclair, Miss Butcher and the two Miss Atwaters got the extinguishers and threw them around the register in the senior boys' classroom and in the hall where the smoke was puffing out. Making no headway, Mr Sinclair cut a hole in the floor near the register and played water on it, but hose was not really long enough. By this time other people had arrived so we turned to salvaging. The first sign of smoke showed near register in senior classroom. The steam pipes on the south side had been repeatedly frozen during the severe cold spell and I was informed that the engineer used to use a blow-torch to thaw them out.

Miss. E. ATWATER. Senior Teacher.

I am the teacher in the senior classroom, which is situated in the south end of the building, immediately over the senior boys' playroom. At 2:10 o'clock, school time, on the afternoon of the fire I was with my class in the classroom when I noticed smoke coming up by the register which was situated along the south wall. I immediately sounded the alarm and filed the children from the room. This was done in perfect order. After turning the children over to the matron I went down to the senior boys' playroom and wash-room, immediately under my classroom. There was considerable smoke in the wash-room and I then went around to the junior boys' playroom and wash-room. In this wash-room I saw flames in a hole which was in the partition between the two wash-rooms. Two boys went at once for fire extinguishers and by this time Mr Sinclair had come down to see the fire, and I was asked by the matron to go to the other end of the building to assist with saving bedding from the dormitories.

Signed.- Elizabeth Atwater.

JOHN KAPAY.

I was on duty in the engine room when the fire started. I did not hear the alarm. Some children outside told me that the school was on fire. Mr Snowden, the engineer came to the engine room and told me to get the pumps working and keep the fires going. The water pressure gauge registered 40 lbs. The pipes in the junior boys' wash-room in the basement were quite often frozen and a blow-torch was used to thaw them out. Sometimes I used the blow-torch alone for this purpose, and sometimes the engineer. I was called the assistant engineer, and was told by the engineer that I should look over the building in very cold weather and if I found pipes were frozen, I was to take a blow-torch and thaw them out. The last time I used a blow-torch was on the Wednesday preceding the fire, I used it on the return pipe in the sewing-room. I never took a shield to place behind the torch when I was using it. I was not told to do so.

Signed.- John Kapay
Evidence in connection with fire at Gordon's School, on Friday February 1st, 1929.

Mr. A.W. Sinclair, Junior Teacher.

At 2:05 p.m., by the schoolclock clock the fire alarm was sounded. My children filed out in perfect order thinking no doubt it was a fire drill. Miss Atwater informed me that there was a fire in the senior classroom, whereupon I rushed to the said room and noticed smoke coming up through the floor boards. Fire extinguishers were brought which were of no use; we manned the hose which was not long enough; started a bucket brigade consisting of Lawrence Anderson, Colin Pratt and Peter Bird. I bashed in the floor in the hall but there was no chance as the fire had already gained headway. Same procedure in the boys' playroom but it seemed beyond control. By this time more people had arrived, so I went to the dormitories with two boys to save beds. From the time these people arrived I was employed saving what was possible. As to the origin of the fire I can only surmise. It may have been matches, but I think not as they could have been too much draught between the boards to allow a match or matches to remain alight. Again it might have been the electric wires, as the smoke was coming out of the floor boards in both stories, also out of the turret. As to the use of the blow-torch, I am in no position to testify or surmise as to whether it was in use that day or not. There is a rumour to that effect. From the time of the fire alarm it could not have been more than two hours before the school fell in.

Signed,

A.W. Sinclair
Junior Teacher.

Mr. E.W. Snowden, Engineer.

I was in my house (the old laundry) when the fire started. It was about fifteen minutes after I left the engine room that I was sent for. The boy who called me said there was fire in the senior play-room. I immediately went to engineeroom and ordered the boy on duty to start the pump. I took an axe and broke windows in senior wash-room and took four extinguishers with me; Peter Bird was with me. The flames were in the partition between the wash-rooms and came right up to the top of the partition to the ceiling. The flames were about two and a half feet up the partition. There was a hole in the partition right through to the junior wash-room. We threw extinguishers on flames but with no effect, and the heat and flames drove us out. I then went to hose on basement floor and turned on water. The hose was too short to reach the wash-room, so I shut off the valve in the basement and took two lengths of the basement hose and added it to the main floor hose and turned on standard on main floor. I then put the garden hose on the tap in the junior wash-room and played this on the flames there. Tommy Bird told me that Kenneth started the fire. The last time I used the blow-torch was in the sewing-room on Wednesday, and the last time I used the blow-torch in the senior wash-rooms was on Monday evening at about 10:30 p.m. At 5 a.m. on Friday I inspected radiator and trap in junior wash-room and found them all right. I did not use blow-torch at any place in the building on Friday. I had sixty pounds water pressure on. There was no short-circuit in electric wiring. The lights were not on.

Signed,

Ernest William Snowden
Engineer

Report of the Principal of Gordon's School re the Fire at the School on February 1st, 1929.

To whom it may concern:

I beg to report that I was in the basement rooms of the School after the mid-day meal on Friday, February 1st and saw no trace of fire anywhere. About 1:15 p.m., I went with the Farm Instructor and Alex Geddes to the Old School to inspect it with a view of making it more comfortable as the Parish Hall. We were not there more than half an hour, after which we returned to the School. On the way back we met some boys who had been sent by the Matron, telling us that there was a fire at the school. We hurried the horses and went direct to the School. We saw the members of the staff working with the chemical fire extinguishers when we went to the attic to see if the fire was there or smoke was seen coming from the upstairs. There was no sign of fire or smoke in the attic at that time. We descended to the main floor and saw smoke coming up from the floor through a broken board. Water was poured into this hole from the fire hose which had been started in the meantime. Then we heard that fire was seen in the senior wash room down stairs and we went down to work on that. As the fire hose was not long enough we disconnected the length on the floor above and joined it on to the length in the basement and the farm instructor played a stream of water through a hole in the ceiling on the joists which were blazing. We thought we had subdued the fire there and gave attention to the Junior play room. Then we were called to bring the hose to the Senior Schoolroom on the floor above. We disconnected the hose and took it to the main floor connected it to the main water pipe and the farm instructor deluged the School room. Then we were called to the Bale room where the fire seemed to be breaking out. Could not enter by the door, so obtained a ladder, broke a window and poured water into the bale room from the hose. Called indoors again to fight fire in Junior play room and main hall. Fire gained and eventually the workers were called out as the interior of the building was becoming impossible owing to flames and dense smoke.

We then decided to fight the fire from outside, but the hose was too short and to make matters worse one length inside the building broke and we could not get to the hydrant to turn off the water to make repairs.

While the fire was being fought in this manner by some of the men, others were using buckets and doing what they could, others with the women and some of the pupils of the school were clearing the building, with the result that almost everything movable was saved. The workers went on until it was dangerous to continue and they were ordered to stand off and carry away the salvaged good to a safe distance. Great praise is due to the staff and the voluntary helpers who came from the Reserve and from Munnichy for their strenuous efforts.

Sir,

In connection with the fire which destroyed the Gordon's Residential School on Friday last, February 1st, I beg to enclose herewith statements which I have obtained from the various members of the staff. I obtained statements only from those who actually saw the fire in its inception. Miss Bray, laundry, Mrs. Collins' kitchen and Mr. Williams' boy's supervision were not engaged at any time in fighting the actual fire, having devoted their time to the work of salvaging as much as possible of the contents of the building.

I received a telephone message at shortly after 1:30 P.M., town time which is about forty minutes later than the Gordon's School time, to the effect that the school was on fire. I immediately made arrangements for the Agency team and bobleigh to proceed through the town to the school, picking up as many helpers as possible from the village. I then received a call from Dr. Phillips that he had engaged a livery team to drive out, so after notifying the R.C.M.P. to look after the matter of getting as many volunteers as possible to go out with our team I proceeded to the school armed with a large sized extinguisher and went out to the school with the doctor. We made very good time galloping all the way out. Passed several Indians on their way to town and turned them back towards the school.

Arrived at the school smoke was to be seen pouring out through the turret at the top of the building. The children and some of the staff were taking stuff from the building and the bedding was practically all out. I went straight in to the senior class room where the smoke appeared to be heaviest and cut hole in floor in effort to locate fire, and then heard someone call that fire had broken out in the candy room which was some ten or twelve yards [?] North of the class room. I went there to investigate and found the place in a blaze. Some of the children and some Indians were lifted up with pails and jugs and held the fire until the hose was brought up from the main floor.

The flames here were extinguished and the hose then taken down to the Junior boys playroom where the ceiling was now burning fiercely. Mr. Stanford and Mr. Holyoak were making desperate efforts to hold the fire here and I took a look at the other side of the partition in to the senior boys playroom. Fire was showing through the top of the partition and in to the ceiling on this side, but with the help of some Indians with pails sufficient water was scooped up from the floor in this room to check the blaze, and then went up to the main floor to see if it would be possible to play on the fire from the top side. The tale room which is over the Junior playroom was forced into but was filled with dense smoke. The hose was turned on this for a short while, but the smoke was too heavy and an attempt was then made to play the hose from the outside of the building through the bale room window. At this stage the whole roof burst into flames, and it was then that I saw Mr. W. Swan who is quite familiar with the lay of the whole building. I asked him if it were possible to save the rest of the building in any way and he said it was impossible as he had just come down from the top storey and that the fire had a strong hold up there. Everyone then turned to the task of getting as much stuff from...
the building as possible. The hose on the main floor was too short to reach right up to the south side of the class room where the first smoke was seen, but there was sufficient pressure to enable one to throw a stream of water across the room. Those who first saw the fire are quite agreed that the first actual flame appeared in the partition between the washrooms on the ground floor on the south side of the building. About two and a half feet from the ground in this partition was a hole where once had been a toilet fixture. It is here that both Miss Lou Atwood and Engineer Snowden saw the first signs of naked flame. The partition wall was of lath and plaster construction and it is my opinion that some of the boys may have been smoking cigarettes after dinner and perhaps the supervisor had come in to the playroom and they had then thrown the remains down into this hole in order to get it out of sight.

In one or two of the statements mention was made of the fact that the engineer had been in the habit of using a blow torch to thaw out frozen pipes. When I heard this first I thought that here was the immediate cause, but if the engineer and his assistant are telling the truth there was no blow torch used in these rooms since the Monday preceding the fire of Friday. It is a fact that Friday was a comparatively mild day and there should have been no frozen pipes on that day. I had no personal knowledge that the engineer was resorting to this highly dangerous practice of using a blow torch in the building else it would have been immediately stopped. Some mention has been made as to the possibility that Kenneth McNab, aged five years, who was adopted by the school when a baby, was responsible for putting lighted matches down into the hole in the partition, but this boy was up on the second storey all morning in the infirmary. I have this from both the doctor and also from one of the boys who was with him. I can find no one who actually saw the engineer using a blow torch in the boys' washrooms on the day of the fire, but there was a rumour to this effect going the rounds.

The power plant might have been saved had there been a hydrant on the outside of the building. The furnaces and boilers I believe are uninjured, and the filter tank and pressure tanks do not appear to be badly damaged. The main building was completely gutted, only portions of the outside wall remaining standing, and these are being pulled down for the sake of safety.

The children were filed out in perfect order, and the younger ones taken over to the old school annex where they were made as comfortable as possible; the older ones remaining to assist with the work of saving as much of the contents of the building as was possible.

The cigarette theory, in the absence of any more tangible, appears to be reasonable for the following reasons. The boys would have come from their dinner at 12:30 going direct to their playroom. School would commence again at 1:30 P.M. A cigarette which is lit to the head of the partition at any time during the forty-minute interval would take some time to set fire to the lath, and it was shortly after 2:00 P.M. that smoke was first discovered. The supervisor has both the senior and junior playrooms to watch and it is not at all improbable that a boy could smoke unknown to him, by going in to the washroom. I shall make further inquiries and if anything new is discovered I will immediately advise you.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham, Esq.,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report of an investigation with reference to the fire at the Gordon's School which occurred last Friday. The report gives a good deal of information, but I regret to say there is nothing definite brought out as to the cause of the fire. The first indication of a fire was smoke coming out of the register immediately above the lavatories and as the outside walls of the basement are of concrete construction the only place it could start would be where there was something that would burn. Once the fire started it would naturally run up between the studding and then along the floor joists in the direction of the bale room where the fire seemed to be the hottest. Dear Mr. Scott:-

Mr. Snowden, who was Engineer in charge at the Gordon Indian Residential School, has just been in my office and has given me an account of the fire that took place there. Mr. Snowden went on duty on Friday morning at 4:45. He inspected the lavatories at about six o'clock and found everything in working order. He again visited them about nine o'clock. He went off duty at noon and after his meal he retired to his room, and had only been there a very short time when a boy ran up to him and told him that the school was on fire. He states that inside of two minutes he was back at the building, and gave his assistant, an Indian boy, instructions to start the engines, which the boy did without any difficulty, and kept the pumps going at sixty pounds pressure all through the fire. He then went to the classroom and found it full of smoke, and Mr. Sinclair, a young, junior teacher, playing the hose on the floor where there were no flames. He rushed outside and broke through the outside window of the lavatory and saw the flames working in the wooden partition dividing the two lavatories—not in the outside wall. He took with him several fire extinguishers but they had little effect on the flames. At the time he was there he was quite satisfied that the flames had not reached the first floor above, and this was the floor they were applying the water on. He told Sinclair, who had the hose upstairs, that it was useless to play the water there, and that he should get the hose around where the fire was. However, this was not done he claims and it was a long time after this before the fire broke through the flooring—probably 35 minutes.

He claims that the fire was in the partition, and the partition only, for a long time. He also informs me that there was a hole in the partition dividing the senior and junior boys' lavatories. Why they ever left this hole in the partition, knowing that boys do often smoke cigarettes and play with matches, is hard to understand. This, in my opinion, shows that someone has been careless.

Patrol Report.

Re: Burning of Gordon Indian Residential School.
Assistance to Indian Agent and Department.

On Friday Feb. 1st, 1929 Mr. S.S. Moore, Indian Agent came to this detachment and requested me to take charge of a relief party enroute to the Gordon Indian residential School as the School was in flames and he was leaving immediately with the medical surgeon.

At his request and upon the instructions of the N.C.O. I/C of this Detachment I gathered together a party of volunteer fire fighters and patrolled to the scene of the fire with the Indian Agency team and sleigh.

Upon my arrival Mr. S.S. Moore with the aid of the Indians of the Gordon Reserve was desperately endeavouring to check the fire which was gutting the north wing of the school which comprised the boys dormitory and playground. From the information I received I gathered that the fire had started between the ceiling of the first floor and the floor of the second. There was only one hose available and this was steadily pouring water into the blaze. The fire was already well under way and although fire extinguishers were applied they were of no avail. After a short time the one water hose broke at the connections and while it was being repaired the flames broke out beyond control and swept the building.

The staff and pupils had been steadily removing the contents of the building and the party of Punnichy Citizens rendered every possible aid in this respect so that the loss was reduced to a minimum. After it became quite evident that the fire had got beyond control I satisfied myself that there were no pupils or others remaining in the School and when the larger portion of the contents were removed I closed the front door into the school to bar further entrance.

While I endeavoured to remove the children to a safe distance from the fire, the Citizens of Punnichy hastily removed the furniture and other contents to a reasonably safe distance and in a short while everything was cleared away from the doomed building and the children were conveyed by team to a place of shelter.

Every effort was put forth by Mr. S.S. Moore, Indian Agent to save the building but his arrival had been too late owing to the school being six miles distant from the town and the slow means of transport as the roads were blocked with snow and it was necessary to drive by team. Within four hours of the first report the flames had completely gutted the building and it was soon a ruined mass.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 9th instant, No. 121-1-1, regarding arrangements that have been made for the care of pupils at the Gordon's Residential School. I may say that, while the Elkhorn School would be considered crowded according to the rules of the Department, I think that with the instructions I have given Mr. Eley there will be ample fresh air supplied the pupils while in the dormitories and the classrooms. My Lord Bishop,

RE Gordon's Indian Residential School

I have entered very carefully into the matter of Gordon's School referred to in your Lordship's recent interview with the Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, and as Chairman of the Indian Committee I feel very deeply the serious consequences which will ensue if the Department should be persuaded to delay the immediate re-building of the same in the face of your Lordship's urgent request.

In the first place I believe reference has been made to the cause of the fire and that the staff has been blamed. In reply to this I would point out that the suggestion that the fire was caused by the dropping of a match into a crack in the plaster in the boys' play room was entirely theoretical. I have visited the School and from the evidence obtained there am of the opinion that the fire commenced in the centre of the building and very close to the bake room and not at the east angle of the building as suggested; also that it is quite possible the origin of the fire may very well have been from exposed wiring caused by mice. The fact that the bake room was unapproachable from the very first seems to support this theory.

With regard to the action of the staff my information is that the children were removed under perfect discipline and with the utmost promptitude and entirely without injury.

The Lord Bishop of Qu'Appelle,

We understand that reference has been made to lack of fire-drill. We have on our files a letter from the previous Principal stating the methods of fire-drill used, which effectually dispenses of this charge.

As the fire was entirely concealed by the inner walls and as it was not a fire proof building the fire defied the utmost efforts of not only the staff but a number of men who immediately came down from Punnichy. So devoted were the efforts of the staff towards the suppression of the fire that they lost practically all their personal effects. It is very doubtful if even an experienced fire brigade could have controlled this fire.

Mention could also be made that with a single hose for each floor and with smoke pouring out in parts of each flat it would not have been possible for a hose to reach every angle of the building on any one flat without securing a hose from another floor. That the water pressure from the engine room was fully maintained is evidenced by the fact that one of the hose was burst in the operation. It all goes to show the positive need of a fire proof building. Our Committee is persuaded that every effort was made on behalf of the staff working under extreme difficulties with the temperature at 25 degrees below zero.

The matter which most deeply concerns the Diocesan Committee at this time is the suggestion of any delay in the matter of re-building the School as we cannot think such a policy would be compatible with the best interests of the Indian children and their parents on our three reserves, viz., Gordon's Indian Reserve, Bay Stars I.R., and Poorman's I.R., nor with the great efforts the Church in this Diocese has made on behalf of Indian Work; nor with the condition of things as they stand as regards expenditure of money and equipment belonging to both the Department and to the Diocese at Gordon's School.

The Diocese has a half section of land adjoining the School on which there are 63 acres under cultivation. We have an Farm Instructor

Mr. John Holyoak, recently of Indian Head, and one of the most experienced cattle men in the Province. During the past year a considerable sum of money has been expended at his request on both implements and stock and he is prepared for most progressive work on our farm land during the ensuing year, with the assistance of the larger boys of the school. If there is to be any delay in proceeding with the re-erection of the school this excellent work behalf of the Indians on the Reserve and the boys in the school will be curtailed. We also have nine children of school age on Poorman's Reserve and nine children of school age on Day Stars Reserve who were attending Gordon's School, together with 44 children from other Reserves who have been removed to Elkhorn School since the fire.

A suggestion has been made as to frequent changes of Principals but we would like to point out that the late Rev. Canon Atwater was thirteen years Principal and although it is true there have been three principals who have left the school since 1925, yet those who have much experience in Indian school work it would indicate that the Diocese is making its utmost efforts to obtain the most efficient man in all the branch of the work entailed in an Indian Residential School and that the fact of having had several changes in evidence that the Diocese has been ceaseless in its efforts to keep in this position only a man of superlative attainments.
The Lord Bishop of Qu'Appelle.

In the present Principal, the Rev. F. Stanford, we believe we have found such a man.

In evidence of the splendid work that the Church has done on this Indian Reserve and in this School we would point out that from the information we are able to obtain it is considered to be the healthiest school and the nearest Reserve of any in Western Canada and that this is largely due to the Principals and their devoted staff in the last twenty years. The absolute devotion of the graduates of this Institution on these Reserves is a living testimony to the excellent work of the Church in the past forty years. During the past two years we have completed and equipped a large Church capable of seating some three hundred and everything surrounding it bears witness to the devotion of the Indians.

Not the least of the most serious effects which would arise out of delay in re-building the school would be the impression left upon the minds of many thousands of parishioners of the Church in this Diocese who have shown their devotion and generosity to our Indian work at Gordon's School, hundreds of whom have visited the School and have seen and appreciated all that we are doing. Almost every branch of the Woman's Auxiliary in our Parish has taken a share in clothing a child of the School by direct yearly contributions. The loss of the School came as a personal shock to many hundreds of our people and it would be an unthinkable thing to them that the most mature and sympathetic consideration would not be given in response to such an appeal on their behalf.

It should be pointed out that if immediate steps can be taken a good deal of the material would be available for the erection of the School, much of which would be spoiled through weathering if there is delay. The boilers, high pressure tanks, and large water filter, together with pumps, pipes and equipment are uninjured, also some of the inner walls, smoke stacks, etc., also the batteries were salvaged, in fact practically all the machinery excepting dynamo and dynamo engine. Immediate care will be necessary to save this portion of the equipment.

Your committee feels that it has your Lordship's deepest sympathy in appealing on behalf of a work which lies very close to the hearts of thousands of our people on the prairie and which has such a real place in the lives of so many as one of the most important Institutions in Western Canada.
The Lord Bishop of Qu'Appelle.

We strongly appeal for the erection of a fire proof building with adequate and frequently tested fire equipment.

Believe me, my Lord,
Your obedient servant,

REGINA, SASK., March 8th, 1929

The Right Honourable,
W. L. MacKenzie King,
Prime Minister of Canada,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. McKenzie King,

The destruction of our Indian Residential School by fire last January inflicted a terrible loss upon the Church in this Diocese of Qu'Appelle. Gordon's Indian School has been the constant care and pride of the Church for seventy years; and now most of the children are scattered, the teachers living in shacks, and the situation very serious as far as our Indian Work is concerned.

The Indian Department and our Church Societies have given us sympathy and ready help, but I have been distressed today in meeting Dr. Duncan Scott in Regina, and in hearing from the Hon. Chas. Stewart, the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, that the Department is not able to promise further grants for Indian Education for the next fiscal year, and that we may be left without our Indian Residential School for some time.

I wish to most earnestly plead, in the name of the Indians, the Clergy, and the Laity throughout this Diocese, living in close upon 500 centres, for the obtaining of a further grant for Indian Education which will allow of the immediate reconstruction of Gordon's School. The situation which the postponement of the reconstruction of the school will create is serious in the extreme. The Staff must be provided for; the farm instruction work must be carried on; the stock must be attended to, and forty children living around must be provided for. Moreover, the foundations of the school are intact, and the furnace and boilers can now be utilized. I should say that an additional sum of ninety to one hundred thousand dollars will make the necessary provision. I feel the situation is so serious that I am leaving for Ottawa after my Confirmations on Sunday to interview the
Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

May I ask your interest and concern in this matter of vital importance to the Indian work and the Church in this Diocese.

With dutiful respects,

I am,

Obdiently yours,

The children were well clothed, but some were very untidy. Their hands were dirty, and only one or two had their hair neatly combed. Sir,—
I beg to report on the Gordon Indian Residential School as follows.

On my visit to the classroom of this school the register showed thirty pupils, twenty one being present, seven working at the school, one away sick, one recently discharged. The classroom was well aired, and fairly tidy but overcrowded. Two of the boys had dirty hands; they did not appear to have been washed this morning so I made them wash before I left. The other boys were clean, and the girls were clean and tidy. The outside of the school is untidy, one closet being perched up on a frame of logs makes it look worse. The principal was asked last month to get the closets put in shape but only one has been moved.

A new boys supervisor named Mr. Mullins has lately taken over the work here, I told him about the boys being dirty.

The kitchen and girls dormitory building was very tidy and clean.

The boys dormitory upstairs from the laundry was clean, having just been scrubbed, but looks very untidy being badly overcrowded.

On my January report I stated that the class room was the dirtiest I ever examined, February and March returns stated matters were in better shape. April return stated that appearance of school was improved classrooms untidy. The conditions make it hard to keep this place spotless and span but I state again as I did in my April return that the pupils could be kept cleaner with very little supervision. The supervision of this place is slack, the Principal seems to be too easy going and good natured.

Each time I have reported anything about this school I have also told the Principal what to do, but I have not time myself to continually having to tell him things he should see himself.

The old ice house and the old laundry at this place should be moved or they will be out of place when the new school is built. The new ice house, girls dormitory, garage, laundry, three barns and dwelling require painting.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned from a visit to Touchwood Agency, and while there I went over to the Gordon's School to see what the situation was like. I found the work was just about being wound up, but nothing had been done to clean up the surroundings, and there is a big job ahead. The workmanship, as far as I could see, was first class.

The object of my visit to the school was to arrange for the erection of an implement shed, storehouse, hen house, and repairs to other out-buildings.

With reference to Mr. Stanford's management, I may say that the yard surrounding his own house was in a disgraceful condition - all littered up, and weeds all over the place. In fact, if an Indian kept his yard in such shape, he would be found fault with by the Agent. The Agent took me over to a field of potatoes a mile away, which were put in for the use of the school. You would have to get out of your car and walk in to find the potatoes. The whole enclosure was one seething mass of weeds. The garden surrounding the school was not much better. A cultivator had been drawn between the rows of potatoes and the weeds. It is a disgraceful situation. This school is situated on the reserve with the idea of developing the Indians along the proper lines, and all I can say is that, having this school under the present management is nothing more than a menace to the progress of the Indians. It also makes it difficult for the Agent to say anything to the Indians about the way in which

way in which they keep their premises when they can turn around and point to the school, which is supposed to be an example. Dear Sir:—

I beg to report that I visited the Gordon Indian Residential School yesterday. There were 13 pupils in the classroom, 14 working around the premises, and one sick.

The new school has been occupied, pupils are sleeping on the floors yet. No furniture has been supplied to this school yet.

The carpenters informed me that when they moved the old hostel used by the girls for sleeping quarters that they found a quantity of bed bugs. I asked the matron if the matresses had been fumigated before being moved into the new school and she said they had not. In the cellar the sewage comes up through the traps and floods the floor when water is let down the drains, I beg to recommend that the contractor be wired to regards this matter, the sewers are not in shape and if used as they are will probably cause typhoid.

Dear Sir,

RE Gordon's Indian Residential School

I have to report that Mr. Rowland W. Frayling was duly installed in his duties as the new Principal of this School on the 8th inst. and has now had time to take over complete charge.

His Lordship has also appointed the Rev. John Rowlands as acting Chaplain of the School and the Church of St. Luke's, Gordon's Indian Reserve, and he has also commenced his duties. The Bishop is preparing for the appointment of a permanent Chaplain in the Spring.

We have been in the closest touch with the new Principal in regard to the furnishings and equipment of the School and have assisted him as far as possible in overcoming the difficulties which have had to be faced through the serious delay of the same.

It is now necessary for us to take up with you the matter of the special grants made to us in lieu of the regular per capita grant. Under this arrangement the former Principal, the Rev. F. Stanford, asked us to make requisition to the Department from time to time for the sum necessary to carry on while we kept things going in the best possible way by providing for some 14 boys and 15 girls in the small buildings around the new school.
Duncan G. Scott, Esq.

and by carrying on a Day School in the Parish Hall on the Reserve.

The Rev. Stanford was required to keep strict account of these monies and an audited statement of account was to be required of him when the system of special grants came to an end by the opening of the new school. These accounts have been kept and this Office is in possession of a statement duly audited by Mr. Sydney A. Brown, the local Auditor at Punnichy. If the Department desires to have this audited statement now, we shall be glad to furnish it.

It was of course our expectation that the new school would be furnished and ready for occupation by July 1st. at the latest. In view of this our children who had been taken to the Elkhorn Indian Industrial School were not received back into that institution after the Summer Vacation, and since then have been with their parents on the reserves awaiting the notice to come to the new school.

Additional staff was arranged for and expected to commence their duties on August 1st. The Farm Instructor, the Engineer, the Boy's Supervisor, one teacher, laundry matron, sewing matron, assistant kitchen matron and acting head matron, have been steadily employed since that time, while the senior kitchen matron, and second teacher were engaged at that time and have been claiming their wages since. This heavy expense has had to be incurred as the new school should have been ready for use since the beginning of July. Farm work, garden work, the heating of the school and much of the work of the Staff has had to be carried on just as if the full quota of children had been in residence. A very competent engineer of long experience has been engaged at a larger salary as per your letter of February 24th., 1930. As the Winter was upon us the expenditure of fuel has also had to be the same, and in addition there has had to be the usual expenditure in feed for the horses and stock, the cost of which has been greatly increased owing to the heavy loss to both crops and gardens sustained through the destruction brought about by the terrific hailstorm early in August. Tons of hay have already been purchased from the Indians on the Reserve.
Duncan C. Scott, Esq.

It is, therefore, imperative for us to appeal to the Department for much increased assistance in the amount of the special grant required in lieu of the per capita grant which we should have been able to draw had the necessary equipment been forthcoming at the time the new school was completed. At least 125 children could have been in residence in the school during the past six months. The full capacity of the new school is 140. The per capita grant for 125 children for the quarter would have been $4,843.75, which is the amount we might have received for the last quarter, a sum which would have been sufficient to cover our needs.

In this connection we would respectfully point out that by the release of 44 children from the Elkhorn Indian School since July the Department was saved the per capita grant for six months at the rate of $170.00 per capita per annum, i.e., $3740.00.

We have had to give an order to the Bank of Montreal, Punnichy, allowing our Principal to overdraw and have further had to assist the finances of the School by drawing upon Diocesan Funds. It seems to us only reasonable that the Department should at least give us a special grant sufficient to offset this additional expenditure. We, therefore, ask, Sir, that the Department would make a grant of $4000.00 for the quarter ending December 31st., 1930. We have so far in this quarter received only $1500.00 on November 22nd. and sorely need the balance of $2500.00. We would also ask that the special grant at the rate of $4000.00 per quarter may be forthcoming until the full per capita grant for the new school may be drawn.

Believe me, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

E. H. Knowles.

I suggested to the Church authorities that Mr. Wallace, the Farming Instructor, be appointed, and I believe he will make good.

I may say that I received a rather adverse report from Nurse Wyatt on this school, but in view of the Inspector's report I am inclined to think that the work of the institution was not properly organized at the time Miss Wyatt was there. The Nurse's report in question is going forward today also.

GORDON'S C. of E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

The new school is now being occupied, and since my last visit, Mr. R. W. Frayling has been appointed Principal.

The senior classroom is in charge of Miss Atwater, and the grades are arranged as follows:

|       | 3   | 7   |

I believe the children are making fair progress, although they do not speak out as well as might be expected, and are somewhat shy. They appear to understand their work, and I found their work books very tidy.

The children were well dressed, clean, and all had their hair neatly combed.

The classroom
GORDON'S C. of E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The classroom was bright, well aired, and tidy.

The junior room is in charge of Mr. F. Lumb, and all the pupils are in Grade 1, or beginners. There are fifty on the roll, 23 boys and 27 girls. I understand Mr. Lumb is a qualified teacher, and I would judge from his style and manner of presenting the work, that fair progress is being made.

The children were neatly dressed and clean. The room was well aired and tidy.

The kitchen is in charge of Mrs. J. Hughson, and I found the meals well prepared. The menu is made out each month by the Principal, and I understand this is strictly adhered to. A copy of the May menu, both for the staff and the children, is attached to this report. The girls are taught to make bread; in fact, all the bread used up until the present is mixed and worked by hand, and the bread in use during my visits was good. Butter making is also taught, although at present the milk supply is not large. More cows are expected to freshen soon, when the cream supply will be much greater.

The laundry is in charge of Mrs. C. Boate, and I found the department being operated in an orderly manner. The machinery is all well cared for, and the room was clean and tidy. The soft water tank is almost full, but no provision was made to connect this up with the laundry. Soft water is needed badly, and a pump should be installed.

Miss Quick is the sewing matron, and appeared quite capable. The girls are taught mending,
GORDON'S C. of E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

darning, and the making of new garments. The work seen was well done.

Miss Field is the girls' supervisor, and I found the dormitories clean, and the beds neatly made. The girls are provided with nightgowns, which I found neatly folded and placed beneath the pillows. The bedding is washed every two weeks.

Mr. P. T. Williams is the boys' supervisor, and I found the dormitory equally as well cared for as the girls'. The toilets were clean and in good working condition.

The machinery and boiler room is in charge of Mr. Angel, and could scarcely be kept in better condition. He is a good worker, and I believe thoroughly understands machinery. The Principal is very fortunate to have secured this man, and I believe that he (the principal) is quite aware of the fact.

The children are weighed each month, and a record is kept. Attached will be found a statement showing each child's weight for January, February, March, and April. It will be noted that in April some of the children lost weight, which, I understand, resulted from the effects of influenza. On my last visit to the school all the children were well, and for May and June, I would expect to find better gains. The keeping of these records entails considerable work, but by so doing one is able to keep a close check on each child, and if no gains are recorded, steps can be taken to find out the trouble before serious sickness sets in.

The dispensary
GORDON'S C. of E. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The dispensary has been painted white, and I found the drugs neatly arranged on the shelves. The Principal's residence is in good condition, and is well furnished and well cared for.

The Farming Instructor's residence has been re-decorated, and is in excellent condition. I understand the work in connection with the cleaning of this house was all done by the staff and pupils.

The outbuildings, I found to be in good repair except for some of the cement foundation under the barn. This should be repaired.

A great amount of work is needed on the grounds and roadways to give this school the surroundings it should have. The Principal has had considerable work done, and hopes, within the next month, to have the place greatly improved. I understand he has secured trees and shrubs to be planted in front of the school and along the main drive, and I have no doubt that within a few years, these surroundings will present a fine appearance.

The Farming Instructor, Mr. S. J. Wallace, appeared to be a good worker, and I believe understands farming. He has a hard task to perform as the farm land is very dirty, and much work will be needed before it is cleaned up and put in good condition.

The Principal, Mr. R. W. Frayling, appears to be greatly interested in his work and anxious to make the school what the Department desires.

Dear Sir,

Re. School Inspector Moir's Report.

I thank you for copy of above mentioned report, which is the first that has been given since my appointment viz; seven years ago.

Taking them in the order as given I will number them from No.1 on.

No.1 Miss Sullivan is not continuing as Kinder Garten teacher.
No.2 Mr. Schunaman and Miss F. Atwater returned to their duties as before.
No.3 In 1936 the K.G. teacher Miss Kelly held a first class interim certificate, at the end of the year like most teachers she left, I told Mr. Moir she was leaving on his inspection visit, he immediately suggested a lady known to him in his own home town (Govan) a music teacher, adding that it was not necessary for a certificated teacher for this room, it resulted in this lady continuing her music profession.
Mr. Moir then suggested a younger sister, which I engaged on his recommendation, she was absolutely unfitted for the position, thus in November, qualified teachers hard to get between terms, answering my advertisement was Miss Sullivan who was in charge from the end of December till this June.

In reference to progress, six of the children in this room entered the school since Easter, and were unable to speak one word of English, when taking this this great handicap into consideration and the short period, there is some excuse. There has been six K.G. teachers in seven years and you will agree that teaching in an Indian School is not always palatable, location and winter...
Isolation and winter/ isolation makes the average teacher look elsewhere for the coming year. This room is not as desirable as one would wish; it is in a part of a large Playroom, but has five windows in it, wooden partition open top and bottom. Mr. Moir this year suggested that Glass should be put in the top and closed in so that it would be more quiet; this would hinder the present ventilation which is good and obtained from the windows West & North in the other part of the playroom.

The Senior Class Rooms are of course built to specifications accepted by the department; these do need ventilation, but there are six large windows in each room and four electric lights, so that I cannot find light shortage.

In reference to the packing case in the K.G. room, it is an open box used for some material the children work with; this room was made and furnished by myself without any cost to the department and solely for the purpose of relieving the other class rooms which were overcrowded, and the senior teachers from having the K.G. children to contend with, which I considered a great hindrance to those more advanced; the fact that exceptional good health prevails shows that the general conditions of the building is not adverse to the children's well-being.

I much appreciate this opportunity of answering the various remarks of the Inspector, as without them, yourself and others may somewhat misconstrue the absolute conditions, both from the teachers' abilities and room facilities.

REGINA, SASK., November 10, 1928.

Dear Sir:

Some time ago I received a letter from R. Malcaster, K. C., of Prince Albert, outlining some complaints made to him by the Indians of Touchwood Agency. It appears that Mr. Malcaster had a meeting with these Indians some time this Fall.

Among the complaints they made was that the Principal of Gordon's School, Mr. Frayling, had, as punishment, confined the children in a cell on bread and water, and cut the girls' hair short. They also asked that a Day School be established on the Reserve.

I took the matter up with Mr. Waddy, and find that the children are sometimes confined to a room as punishment, but it is by no means a cell, but a room overlooking the entrance, well-lighted and with a good view. With regard to cutting the girls' hair, Mr. Frayling admits doing this as a second-offence punishment for running away. I advised Mr. Malcaster of these facts, and stated that in my opinion the punishments were not too severe, nor did I think they had any cause for complaint.

Mr. Malcaster replied, under date of October 27th, as follows:

"I have this morning received yours of 25th inst., for which I am very much obliged. I note the information you have received, which is not in accordance with the statements made by you to me.

"I consider that the cutting of the hair of children is not a proper punishment, and in the case of girls I consider it constitutes an assault; and unless this practice is stopped, at any rate in the case of girls, my advice must be to lay an information against the principal for assault. I trust such may not be necessary, and that you will see your way to advise the principal that in the case of girls this practice should be stopped.

"The whole difficulty appears to arise in connection with the absence of a Day School, and on behalf of the Chief and Councilors of this Reserve, I hereby make formal demand for a Day School in terms of the Treaty. In this connection I annex copy of a letter I have this morning received from the Chief of Poorman demanding a Day School."

In checking over the Poorman's Reserve, I find there are 30 children attending Muscowequan School, and 14 attending Gordon's, that is, about one-third are Protestant and two-thirds Roman Catholic. The Indians do not live in villages, but scattered all over the Reserve. Under these conditions, with a Protestant and a Roman Catholic School on the Agency, it appears to me that no consideration should be given to the establishment of a Day School on this Reserve at the present time.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

INDIAN BOY FROZEN ON BUSH TRAIL

Frozen body of 11-year-old Andrew Gordon, student at the residential school on Gordon's Island reserve near Punnichy, was found Tuesday afternoon by the boy's father only a mile from home, and seven miles from the school.

The young boy was a grandson of the late Moses Gordon, 87-year-old Cree Indian and chief of the Gordon tribe, who died early this year. He was the oldest Indian chief in Canada.

STOPPED TO REST FOR A TIME

Son of Mr. and Mrs. David Gordon, the boy had apparently left school Saturday morning to visit his parents and had trudged, thinly clad, more than four miles through deep, heavy snow from three to five feet deep.

Marks in the snow indicated he had walked several times before, overcome with exhaustion, fallen into the snow and froze to death. It is expected an inquest will be held.

Neither young Gordon's parents nor pupils knew of his disappearance from school until visitors brought news to Mr. and Mrs. Gordon on Monday evening.

Mr. Gordon started out to search for the boy Tuesday morning, and in the afternoon found the frozen body in the woods a mile from home and seven miles from the school.

Corp. J. H. Gould, R.C.M.P., and Dr. J. P. F. Nelles, the coroner, were notified. The body was taken to Punnichy early Wednesday, and investigation begun.

TEMPERATURE CONTINUES LOW

Saskatchewan was recovering Wednesday from the fierce blizzard that swept the prairies Monday, but the mercury had fallen far down the tube to the lowest point yet recorded.

Low point was reached about 4:30 a.m. Wednesday, when 23 below zero was officially recorded in Regina. Mercury began to climb shortly after 6:30 a.m. and had moved up to 20 below zero at noon to one below zero. A little snow fell during the day and the forecast was for fair and cold with light winds.

Roads throughout the province were slowly being reopened for motor travel.

Dear Sir:-

I regret to report the death of Andrew Gordon, pupil #280 of Gordon's Indian Residential School, the son of David Gordon Jr. #116 Gordon's Band. The following is the report to the best of my knowledge.

On Saturday afternoon March 11th 1939, Mr. Tooley, the Boys Supervisor at Gordon's School, advised the Principal of the School, Mr. R.W. Prayling, that pupil Andrew Gordon was missing. The Principal asked some Indians who were in the office if they had seen the boy, and they answered "No". He told them to bring the boy back if they found him when they went home.

Mr. Tooley had been out with 35 boys all afternoon on play grounds near the lake, and the last time he remembers seeing Andrew was about 3 o'clock p.m. He actually checked the boys at 5:15 p.m. and discovered Andrew was missing. He then reported it to the Principal.

It appears that one old Indian named George Bitternose actually saw the boy a few miles south of the School that evening, but the boy would not stop when he called to him.

Andrew Gordon's home is about seven miles from the School, most of the distance being through heavy bush country. I will call this the first day.

On the second day, Sunday the 12th, the Principal sent the Supervisor to investigate further, and in the afternoon the latter called at the house of John Fisher, who lives near the School, and was told, he says, that Andrew's grandfather had left for Andrew's home that day. Mr. Tooley understood the boy had returned home, but he does not say what gave him to understand this. Mrs. Fisher stated that on this day Mr. Tooley was at her house and she told him that Andrew was not there. She also told him that David Gordon Senior (a relative) had gone to the "mountain", a part of the Reserve near where Andrew's home is situated. She said that David, before he left, did not know that Andrew was missing, and if Andrew had been at their house they would have returned him to the School. The boy playing at Fisher's house was their own boy.

On the third day, Monday the 13th, David Gordon Sr. came back to Fisher's house, and was told that Andrew was missing. David went back to the hills to Victor Gordon's house and told Mrs. Victor Gordon about it. That night they saw David Gordon Jr., the father of the missing boy, and told him that Andrew was missing. This was late at night.

INDIAN BOY FROZEN ON BUSH TRAIL

Frozen body of 11-year-old Andrew Gordon, student at the residential school on Gordon's Indian reserve near Punnichy, was found Tuesday afternoon by the boy's father only a mile from home, and seven miles from the school.

The young boy was a grandson of the late Moses Gordon, 87-year-old Cree Indian and chief of the Gordon tribe, who died early this year. He was the oldest Indian chief in Canada.

STOPPED TO REST FIVE TIMES

Son of Mr. and Mrs. David Gordon, the boy had apparently left school Saturday afternoon to visit his parents and had trudged, thinly-clad, more than four miles through dense woods and snow from three to five feet deep.

Marks in the snow indicated he had stopped to rest five times before, overcome with exhaustion, he sank into the snow and froze to death. It is expected an inquest will be held.

Neither young Gordon's parents nor police heard of his disappearance from school until visitors brought news to Mr. and Mrs. Gordon on Monday evening.

Mr. Gordon started out to search for the boy Tuesday morning and in the afternoon found the frozen body in the woods a mile from home and seven miles from the school.

Corp. A. S. Band, R.C.M.P., and Dr. A. P. F. Nelles, Raymore, coroner, were summoned. The body was taken to Punnichy early Wednesday, and an investigation begun.

On Monday at 7 P.M. Baptiste Pelletier told me he said I believe your boy ran away from school and went across the summer trail. Then I didn't quite believe his statement but I had no official notice and on Tuesday morning I figured I would go and see Mr. Frayling about the matter.

Then right after breakfast on Tuesday I started off from my home alone across country for Gordon School on snow shoes. I had gone about a mile from my home when I saw tracks which I was pretty well sure were my boy's tracks, they were going east, I was then headed west. When I discovered the tracks, I followed them up the trail, this is what is now the old trail, and went about fifty yards and discovered a place where it appeared that the boy had first laid down. Then I continued to follow the tracks and about twenty yards saw where the boy had again laid down in the snow, then continued and found a third place where he had laid down again, then I went on about ten yards and found another place where he had laid down. I continued tracking to last but and fifth place where he had laid down. About another ten yards I followed on and the sixth place I found his body. This was about twenty-five yards from the last place where he had laid down. He was right in the centre of the trail and there was a depth of from three to five feet of snow in places.
