Dear Sir:

In accordance with your radiogram of March 21st, I have visited Gordon's School and enquired into the circumstances of the death of Andrew Gordon, an 11-year-old pupil of that school. I now beg to submit my report:

About 1.45 p.m. on Saturday, March 11th, forty-six boys, including Andrew, were taken by the boys' supervisor, Mr. Tooley, to a lake about 250 yards West of the School, where they skated and slid until about 4.30, when they were taken back to the playground at the School.

At about 5.15 p.m. Mr. Tooley checked the boys in and found that Andrew was missing. Nothing more was seen or heard of this boy until his body was found within three-quarters of a mile of his father's home, unless it was he that was seen about dusk that same evening by George Bitternose, an Indian living between two and three miles south of the School and on the road leading to Andrew's home.

Bitternose at that time saw a boy near his home, but not knowing that one had run away from the School, thought it was some boy who had come to play with his children. When the boy saw Bitternose he started to run away and would not stop, although he, Bitternose, called to him. Bitternose, thinking he was a local boy, thought nothing more about it until after the body was found.

It is not known whether the boy left from the Lake or the Playground, as they were not checked in until three-quarters of an hour after coming in off the Lake. It is, however, known that he left some time between 3.00 and 5.15 p.m., as an aeroplane passed over at 3.00 p.m. and Mr. Tooley distinctly remembers seeing him looking at the plane, but neither Mr. Tooley nor the other boys remember seeing him after that time.

At 5.15, upon finding the boy missing, Mr. Tooley reported that fact to Mr. Frayling, the Principal, who then made enquiries of three Indians, namely, Harry Bitternose, John Bitternose, and another, who had just come in with loads of wood from the south, if they had seen anything of Andrew on the road. They stated they had not. Mr. Frayling then asked them to be on the lookout for him and if they saw him to bring him back to the School and he would pay them for so doing. Mr. Tooley also went down to the Lake to see if he could see anything of the boy or find any tracks. He found no trace of the boy and the snow was so tracked over that it was impossible to find anything.

On Sunday, March 12th, Mr. Frayling heard that the boy was with a relative living near John Fisher, who lives about half a mile from the School, across the Lake west. (The relative referred to is David Gordon Sr., whom they refer to as Grandfather, although he is an uncle, not a grandfather.) He instructed Mr. Tooley to investigate.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Mr. Tooley reported that he was told that Andrew Gordon's grandfather had left for Andrew's home, and understood then that Andrew had arrived home. Mr. Tooley, when questioned as to why he came to such a conclusion, offered no reason.

Mrs. Fisher, when questioned, made the following statement:

"On Sunday, March 12th, Mr. Tooley called at my home and asked me if I had seen anything of Andrew Gordon, at the same time telling me that he had seen a boy around my yard that day and thought it might be he. I replied that the boy he saw was my boy, that Andrew had not been here, that if he had his grandfather would have returned him to the School. I told him that grandfather had left for Andrew's home that morning. Mr. Tooley then left."

Mrs. Fisher then informed me that, although grandfather had started for Andrew's home that morning, that he only went half way and then returned home. However, on finding that the boy was missing he left again on Monday morning to inform the boy's father. She also stated that the members of the Band were very much dissatisfied, that they felt they should have been notified and a search party organized.

Mr. Waddy confirms Mrs. Fisher's statement that grandfather carried the information of the missing boy to the boy's father on Monday. Mr. Waddy also informed me that when grandfather reached the home, the father was away and did not return until after dark.

It will be noted that this disagrees with the police statement, in which they stated that Baptiste Pelletier first gave him the information at 7.00 p.m. Monday. This point, however, is immaterial, as they may both have been there. It, however, confirms the fact that the father knew nothing of the boy's having left the school, until after dark Monday night.

At daybreak on Tuesday morning, March 14th, the father put on his snowshoes and started out to get information. About a mile from home he discovered tracks leading in the opposite direction to which he was travelling. He decided they were his son's tracks, turned, and followed them. He found that the person had fallen five times in a short distance, and then found his son lying on his back, frozen, with his left arm sticking up.

I might point out here that this man lives in a very isolated place, a considerable distance from any other house, and in the woods. (He is a hunter and trapper.) There are two ways of getting to his place—what they call a summer and a winter road. He is seven miles from the School by the summer road and eleven miles by the winter road. The summer road is impassable for a team in winter, and this is the road the boy took. At that time there was from three to five feet of snow on this road. A rough sketch showing the roads is attached.

The father, David Gordon Jr., upon finding the body, proceeded to a white farmer's house south of the Reserve and phoned the Agency, about 11.00 a.m. Mr. Waddy was at that time on Poorman's Reserve and did not return until 6.00 p.m. Mr. Stuart, however, immediately got in touch with the Police, the coroner and the School.

The Police were instructed by the coroner that if there was no evidence of foul play, they were to bring the body to the Agency, which was done, and they arrived there about 4.00 a.m. Wednesday morning. The coroner arrived between 4.00 and 5.00 a.m. and, after viewing the body, decided an inquest was not necessary, and issued a certificate of death, due to exhaustion from exposure to cold.

When the body.......
Report, death of Andrew Gordon.

When the body was brought in, the clothing from the waist down was frozen to the body, due, no doubt, to wading through deep wet snow on Saturday, the day he ran away, as the temperature was 35 degrees above zero that day at noon.

The body was thawed out and the clothing removed. The body was carefully examined for any marks or abrasions of any kind, but none were found. This was done in the presence of Mr. Waddy, the Police, and the boy's father. The father expressed himself as perfectly satisfied that the boy had not been beaten or abused in any way.

In my enquiry, I carefully checked up with Fr. Frayling the methods he uses to prevent truancy, and I cannot find this boy's escape was due to any negligence on the part of the School officials.

I also attempted to find some reason for the boy's leaving, but failed to find any. I found that the boy had not been punished for anything, that he was apparently happy and contented. I questioned his two closest boy chums, Sydney Bird and Banny Childs, as to whether they knew of any reason, whether they had ever heard him complain of the School or his treatment, or whether they had ever said anything about running away. They stated that they had not, but one of them suggested he might have been homesick. I could not find any reason for his going, none, at least, for which the school or officials could be in any way held responsible.

I informed Mr. Frayling that I could not find that the boy's escape was due to any negligence on their part, or that his running away was due to any fault of the School. The question was, was the boy's death due to lack of action on the part of the School after he had run away?

Mr. Frayling stated that in cases of truancy of children from other Reserves, he always notified the Agent, but that in cases of children on that Reserve, he had not done so, and had not thought it necessary, due to their being so near their homes. With regard to following a boy who had run away, his experience had been that it was practically useless, as they were watching for pursuers and, at the first sound of a team, they would take to the woods and hide.

---

The information received during the course of my enquiry may be summed up as follows:

Andrew Gordon, a pupil of Gordon's School, ran away from the School between the hours of 3.00 and 5.15 p.m. on Saturday, March 11th. His absence was discovered at 5.15 p.m. by the supervisor, who immediately advised Mr. Frayling, the Principal. Mr. Frayling immediately enquired of three Indians who had just come in with loads of wood from the south, in which direction the boy's home lay, if they had seen the boy, and upon their stating that they had not, he asked them to be on the lookout for him—if they saw him, to return him to the School and he would pay them for so doing. The supervisor, Mr. Tooley, also went down to the Lake where the boys had been that afternoon, to see if he could find any trace of him.

On Sunday, March 11th, Mr. Tooley enquired of Mrs. Fisher, an Indian woman living about one half mile west of the School, if she had seen the boy, and was informed that the boy's so-called grandfather had left for the boy's home that morning.

On Monday, y...........
On Monday, March 13, Mr. Frayling enquired as to whether anything had been heard. At 7.00 p.m. the boy's father was advised by another Indian that his boy had run away. On Tuesday morning the boy's father found the boy's body about three-quarters of a mile from his home, and at about 11.00 a.m. notified the Agency. Mr. Stuart, Agency Clerk, at once notified the Police, coroner and school. The telephone call from the boy's father, saying that he had found his son's body, was the first intimation the Agent or Police had that the boy was missing, and the Farming Instructor first learned of it from the Police when they were after the body.

On Wednesday, March 15th, the body was taken to the Agency at about 4.00 a.m. and shortly after was viewed by the coroner, who decided an inquest was not necessary.

The weather conditions at that time were:
Saturday, temperature 35 above at noon, turning cold at night.
Sunday, cold.
Monday, cold with a bad blizzard.

Dear Sir:

Under separate cover, I am forwarding report on the fatality at Gordon's School.

You will note that in this report I have just stated the facts in the case, making no comments. You will note by the report that practically no effort was made to trace this boy; that the boy's uncle (so-called grandfather) lives within half a mile of the School, but no effort was made to advise him until Sunday afternoon.

The Principal made a mistake, there is no question about that. However, nothing can be done now to rectify it, and I do not believe that he will ever make another of that kind. The only question now is, what effect is it going to have on the School? There is considerable dissatisfaction among the Indians. They feel that they should have been notified and a search party got out, and there is no doubt in my mind that, if this had been done, the boy would be alive today.

In discussing the matter with Mr. Waddy, he feels that Mr. Frayling has lost the confidence of the Indians and that he should be transferred to some other school. Archdeacon Irwin was in yesterday. He also feels that proper efforts were not made to trace the boy. He informs me, however, that they have no other school to which they could transfer him, and he would like to see him given a severe reprimand and left where he is.

It is my opinion that we should wait for at least another month and find just what the reaction of the Indians is going to be, before making any decision as to what should be done.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Ottawa, April 9, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a report dated March 29, 1939, submitted to the Department by Dr. Robertson, immediately following his investigation of the circumstances that led to the death of Andrew Gordon, an 11 year old pupil enrolled at your school.

Dr. Robertson, in his report, states:

"I informed Mr. Frayling that I could not find that the boy's escape was due to any negligence on his part or that his running away was due to any fault of the school. The question was - was the boy's death due to lack of action on the part of the school staff after he (the boy) had run away?"

I am anxious that you should discuss the circumstances of this boy's death again with the Agent and, if convenient, with Dr. Robertson. It seems to me that, following the escape of a pupil from a residential school, certain steps should be immediately taken. These steps in my judgment are:

1. The information should be conveyed to the agent and to any police officials that may be available in the community;

2. A search should be instituted at once.

The fact that a boy may take to the bush or that it may be difficult to find him is in my judgment no reason whatever why a search should not be organized.

In fact -

R. W. Frayling, Esq.,
Principal,
Gordon's Residential School,
Punnichy, Sask.
In fact, the Principal himself, in his own interests and in the interests of his staff, should take these steps. Public opinion will have very little sympathy with the members of a school staff who refuse to follow an escaped pupil simply because it may be difficult to find him.

Of course, I am not familiar with local conditions, although Dr. Robertson very kindly enclosed a sketch map of the district with his report. I am very anxious, however, that the reputation of our residential schools should be maintained and that Indian parents should be able to send their children to these schools from year to year with the full assurance that they will be protected from all hazards by the members of the teaching staff. In view of the fact that a great many Indian parents appear to be prejudiced against Indian residential schools, it is particularly desirable that we should do everything possible to remove any suspicion or distrust that may exist in the minds of Indian parents.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Ottawa, April 8, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment a report dated March 29, 1939, sent forward by you immediately following your investigation of the circumstances leading to the death of Andrew Gordon, of the Gordon's Indian Residential School.

I note with interest your statement "that you could not find the boy's escape was due to any negligence on the part of the Principal or that his running away was due to any fault of the school". In view of all the circumstances, it is just possible that the Principal and the members of the staff did all that they considered necessary to find this boy after his departure from the institution.

I am convinced that when a pupil is missing from a residential school immediate steps should be taken by the Principal to notify the police and in addition to this to institute an immediate search. The fact that the boy may take refuge in the bush or the fact that it may be difficult to find him is in my judgment no justification whatever for not making an immediate search. It has occurred to me that these steps should be taken by the Principal in his own interests. Public opinion will have very little sympathy with a principal who does not do all that is humanly possible to find and bring back to the school pupils who may escape, particularly during the winter months.

I desire to thank you for your report, which seems to cover the circumstances of this case very thoroughly. I am today communicating with Mr. Frayling, the Principal.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

"That the school system be altered so that they will have a larger measure of control over the raising of their children. Apparently the Gordon's School is much below par as they claim none of their graduates are admitted into the high school at Brandon".

The Gordon's Indian Residential School, Punnichy, Sask., is operated by the Government, in cooperation with the Anglican Church. This school, unlike a great many residential schools operated by the Anglican Church, is operated under the direct supervision of the Bishop of Qu'Appelle. The majority of the Anglican schools are operated under the direction of the Indian and Eskimo Residential School Commission, with the Secretary's headquarters in Winnipeg.

This school had at the time of the last Inspector's report an authorized pupil enrolment of 120 and the following members of the staff were in charge of the institution:

In addition to the Principal and the teachers, Miss B. Atwater is employed as matron, Mrs. C. Ryel as seamstress and sewing instructor and Mr. L. Tooley boys' supervisor; Mr. J. Wallace is farming instructor and Reverend J. J. Woods, Chaplain.

The officials find it difficult to understand the reference in your communication to the Brandon High School. It has been the policy of the Department during the last three or four year period to emphasize increasingly the importance of vocational instruction in the training of Indian pupils. It has been suggested in circular letters sent out from time to time that at least one-third of the actual classroom period be devoted to vocational projects. Boys are given instruction in farming, carpentry work, blacksmithing, etc., and girls, in hand loom weaving, crochet work, sewing, home-making, etc. It will thus be seen that it is considered inadvisable for the principals of our schools to follow slavishly the provincial curricula. However, there is no obstacle placed in the way of an Indian pupil who displays an unusual aptitude for abstract study. Such pupils are encouraged to proceed with the regular public school and high school courses.

The Inspector's reports on the Gordon's School have been uniformly satisfactory over a period of years, with the exception of over-crowding in the kindergarten class, referred to by the Inspector in his report of October 18, 1929. There has not been an adverse report on the classroom work at this school at any time in recent years. The present principal was selected by the Bishop of Qu'Appelle and by Commissioner Graham. It is my understanding that he was selected in the hope that a layman rather than a clergyman would prove more acceptable.
acceptable to the Indian parents.

Dear Sir:

Re letter 121-1-1 of Nov 13th re Gordon Indian Residential School.

There are two large class rooms here which are used for the larger pupils, one for girls and one for boys. A kindergarten was required, so a room is made at the east end of girls play room. The General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, Mr. Christianson, has sent forward Inspector Moir's report on the Gordon Indian Residential School. This report, I note, is dated October 22, 1940.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

I am in receipt of your letter of the 29th. ult. Mr. R.W. Frayling, as far as I know had no teaching experience prior to his appointment as Principal of Gordon's Indian School, but was a business man.

His appointment took place under my predecessor (now Archbishop of Rupert's Land) but I was then his Archdeacon and Chairman of the Indian Committee of the Diocese, hence my knowledge of the matter. I remember very well journeying to Ottawa with Bishop Harding to see Dr. Duncan C. Scott of the Department of Indian Affairs who had requested the removal of the Rev. F. Stanford, Principal of Gordon's Indian Residential School. At this interview Dr. Scott insisted that a new Principal be appointed who would be a business man, a man of executive ability; as he felt that the institution required one of such capacity who would have experience in the purchasing of goods and supplies and who would devote his time entirely to the management of the institution. The bishop urged the appointment of another clergyman, but Dr. Scott was entirely against it; so also was Indian Commissioner Graham.

It was Commissioner Graham who found and recommended Mr. R.W. Frayling and eventually my predecessor concurred in the appointment.

There is no question to my mind that Mr. Frayling is a man who has shown marked ability in the management
Mr. R.A. Hoey,

of the financial and executive end of things at Gordon's School, and as far as I know has satisfied the Department in that way.

For many years the Principal, whether a clergyman or layman, has not been a teacher in the school, as it requires his whole time to be expended upon the management of the institution of this size with a staff of the number required for all its departments, including the farm, the engineering, the clothing, as well as the education and religious training of the pupils.

I am,
Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

Replying to your letter of the 4th regarding this school, and more particularly the kindergarten classroom accommodation, school pupils' standing, and Miss Fidler, primary teacher.

In 1930 the classrooms were mixed, boys and girls, in one running up to Grade III and the other having pupils up to the age limit for discharge, then 18 years, children more especially at that time unable to speak English on entry. Discipline was difficult in both rooms and justice was not done to either teacher or pupils. To remedy this on reassembling after holidays of 1931 I had a part of the girls' large playroom partitioned off for a Primary Room, engaging an extra teacher so that better results might be obtained in the higher grades, also separating the boys from the girls, grading from I to VIII. The change was so marked that Mr. Moir complimented me on the same. Prior to this he
had to take some of the children in another room to question and hear them read.

It is not really a basement or dug-out. It is more of a first floor. Playroom, dining-rooms (both staff and children's) are all on the same floor. They are level with the ground surface. As a matter of fact there is, or can be, a straight current of air from East to West through this Primary Room and the Playroom, whereas in the other two classrooms, one facing North, the other South, there is no outlet whatever when the door is shut. I do not wish to imply that the Primary Room is what it might be, but there is a greater circulation of air there than in either of the others.

The finding by Mr. Moir of the Primary Room door locked was after he had inspected the room, and after school hours. Miss Kidler, I find, had occasion to leave the room in question for a few moments, and left these little girls to clean it up. It has not happened before nor will it again. Before Mr. Moir left the school he came to the office as usual, and on my asking his findings they were very satisfactory, other than it was a pity changes had to be so frequent in the Boys' Classroom. I reminded him of promising to help me in that direction, which he admitted, and remarked that it was difficult, but that the position here was very much better than the average country school. But the difficulty, as I pointed out to him, is the war, and we all know that every available man's duty is to help to protect our country and win the war, hence the shortage.

Mr. Moir on one occasion suggested a Miss Walker as teacher in the Primary Room, who had her Grade XII, but no teaching ability whatsoever, he saying that it was not necessary for that room. I soon had to ask
for Miss Walker's resignation, to which I think perhaps Mr. Moir took umbrage. On speaking of Miss Fidler he said he thought she would make good, as she purposes going to Normal this next year. He did not mention having found the door locked, which he might have done. The matter could then have been taken up right away and so dispensed with. It was nothing alarming as no harm could possibly come to them in any way, -no fireplace and the room looking right at the front of the school building.

The Gordon's School is a new building, built in 1929 and to the specifications of the Department. I think improvement could have been made in respect to the classrooms, but the ordinary visitor when looking over, thinks everything is just wonderful, and that wonderful provision is made for the Indian children.

Answering the matter of letters having reached you in respect to the learning of the pupils, naming the Grade V as the highest obtained is most untruthful. I have just gone over some of the Discharge Sheets (same will be on your File possibly) and find there were 22 in Grade VI, 24 in Grade VII and 1 in Grade VIII. Many children come into school at ages from 12 to 15, having attended Day School in some cases, and leave at 16 years. How is it possible to show very marked improvement at such age of entry? The reason for this late entry in some cases because here at Gordon's on leaving school (providing there has been good behaviour) we outfit them from head to foot with enough clothes to last for a considerable time.

I have heard that Mr. Glit. Castleden, our Member, has been giving the Indians interviews and to whom they (the Indians) vent their feelings respecting other parts of the Indian Department as well as the schools. There are a few Indians on each Reserve who are agitators. They don't work to try and improve their condition, but just keep on trying to
raise discord. I would appreciate Mr. Castleden's visit to the school, and can assure you that no special preparations would be made, as I endeavour to keep the school fit for inspection at all times.

This is a very lengthy epistle, but to give you the facts as though you were here is what I gather you wish. I shall as in the past be most pleased to do anything for the improvement and advancement of the Indian child, and will gladly welcome any suggestion to that end.

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

As instructed, I am answering the questions asked by the Department.

Age,- born in England, July 3rd, 1871.

Teaching Experience,- Nil.

Qualifications,- Business Course; Service in Imperial Army, 1900, Canadian, 1915; Hotel & Catering, London, England and Montreal; Supervisor of Construction; Commercial Traveller; Deputy Sheriff. Grade on leaving School, Standard 10, English Grammar School.

Re Appointment. In 1930 Mr. Commissioner Graham asked me if I would consider such a position. I told him I had not any teaching experience. He replied that was not essential, business acumen and financing were most needed. He recommended me to the Right Rev. M.M. Harding, then Bishop of Qu'Appelle (now Archbishop of Rupert's Land) and to our present bishop, the Right Rev. E.H. Knowles, who was then Secretary of Synod. They took the matter up with Deputy Supt. General Mr. Duncan Scott, an agree-
able settlement was arranged and at a salary of $100 per month, which is paid by the Synod of Qu'Appelle, and by whom my contract was made. Living quarters etc. are provided by the Department of Indian Affairs out of the per capita grant.

My instructions on taking over were to put the House in Order and be careful of finances. Mr. Duncan Scott suggested it necessary for a Layman to be Principal (prior to which it had been a Cleric) with business ability and initiative to overcome the difficulties then existing. This has been accomplished, and for many years now a substantial credit balance has been shown, which can be verified by the yearly Principal's Report for Fiscal Year ordered by the Department and also the Department Auditor. For instance, March 31/40 had the Per Capita Grant been in hand a surplus of $4534.87 would be shown with no outstanding accounts. These yearly surpluses go back in up-keep and improvements to buildings etc.

Among the numerous officials visiting, those from Ottawa are Mr. J. Sutherland, Dr. Harold McGill, Dr. J.J. Wall and Mr. M. Christiansen, Gen. Supt. of Agencies, also many Church Dignitaries. One of more than ordinary knowledge of such institutions said that this school was second to none in the Dominion, and he has visited most of them. All expressed their approval of the condition and general routine here.

Trusting this statement is of the nature required, will remain

Yours truly,

Ottawa, November 6th, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to requisition dated October 25th, for classroom material for the Gordon's Indian Residential School, it is noted that you request the "Everyday Arithmetic" for Grades 4 and 5. The "Canadian Problem and Practice Arithmetic" is in use in practically all Indian schools in Canada and has been found very satisfactory. In checking over requisitions from your school, it is noted that 12 copies of Book I and 12 copies of Book 2 were supplied in February, last. We desire this latter arithmetic used in your school and if additional copies are required, please let us know at once, as we are holding your requisition until we hear from you.

It is also noted that you request 12 copies of "Far Away People", and in this case, too, we desire you to use the "New Geography" by Frye-Gamell. You are, no doubt, familiar with this Geography, as copies have already been supplied to your school. Please state if additional copies are required.

Ottawa,
October 22, 1942.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his recent inspection of the Gordon's Indian Residential School Inspector Moir states that Grade 7 pupils did not have the necessary books. He also mentions a shortage of material necessary for handwork and other activities. I find that the last requisition received from the Gordon's School was dated March 7, 1942, and no request was contained on that requisition for supplies for Grade 7. As you are aware, supplies are becoming scarce and the Department cannot always allow all the articles requested by schools. At the same time we do not desire to have any grade without textbooks. However, it is difficult to supply these if we do not receive a requisition. It would be appreciated if you would discuss the matter with the Principal of the Gordon's School.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

Reply to Letter 121-14.

Provincial School Inspector Moir did not mention to either of the teachers or myself anything regarding Junior Red Cross Magazine or Canadian Nature magazine, both of which are received here, and I most certainly did not think it necessary for me to show these magazines to the Inspector, more especially after receiving them for so long a period. It would be interesting to know what is particularly lacking in knowledge by these magazines not being shown to the Inspector, also an outline as to his general findings in the classrooms.

You will of course know the handicap in procuring teachers since hostilities, and I would much appreciate your assistance in procuring the services of a teacher for the Boys' Classroom, Grades I to VIII, as the present teacher is leaving to study for the higher grades. The salary paid is $65.00 per month with room, board, laundry and white uniforms.
Ottawa,
November 26, 1943.

Dear Sir:

I note from your letter of the 20th instant, that you are receiving the Junior Red Cross Magazine and the Canadian Nature Magazine regularly. Unfortunately these magazines were not in the classrooms where they should be, as otherwise the Inspector would have seen them.

In his report Inspector Moir wrote as follows regarding teaching methods:

"Miss Atwater's influence in the school is cumulative. Her long association with these girls and even their parents and her kindness count for more in her success than her methods. She is following Saskatchewan curriculum more closely.

"Miss Sloan has broadened her work and is using many teaching devices; she has purchased a radio and will use it in the classroom.

"Miss Welsh is handicapped by cramped quarters and lack of teaching experience. Emphasis mainly on written work and drawing rather than on oral language.

"Many of the suggestions made in the previous report and in discussions with the teachers are being carried out. Miss Atwater takes music in the two senior rooms and is bringing the work to a satisfactory level. In both rooms the work is approaching the grade

Mr. R.W. Frayling,
Principal,
Gordon's Indian Residential School,
Punnichy, Sask.
levels of the province in the majority of subjects. The written language exercises were very satisfactory. Oral language remains the chief problem in all three rooms - the out-of-class speech seems at a higher level than the speech in the classrooms, perhaps because much of the classroom work is not adjusted to the felt needs and interests of the children. In the kindergarten there should be more opportunity for speech, more activities in social studies, health, and nature study."

Mr. Moir suggested that additional supplementary reading material be supplied and an order for this was placed with the Government Stationery Office on the 22nd instant.

I regret that we are not in a position to nominate a teacher for your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

I am very sorry that I did not use the standard requisition forms but I found it had but a few of the books I require.

I find that the children are in great need of a lot of language practice. The language books we requisitioned are recommended by the Dept. of Education in Saskatchewan and I could really make good use of them.

The provision of additional library reference material either in the nature of an encyclopedia or a magazine such as the "Canadian Geographic" is recommended. Other classroom aids such as phonograph records, a Viewmaster and Autoharp can be used to good advantage in this class room.

Sir:

I beg to state that last week I visited Fort Qu'Appelle in company with Mr. Finlayson, to gather information as to the best method of building and how much exactly can be done with the amount of grant placed by your Department at our disposal.

We found that it would be impossible to build anything larger than 41 x 48 ft. with that amount. We therefore have decided to spend a portion of the grant to repair or rather finish the old building and to fit them up for school room and boys' dormitories, office and printing room and boys' lavatory. In short make the place comfortable enough to last a few years till we can procure money to build another cottage for the boys similar to the one we propose to build now for the girls and household accommodation.

We propose, with your sanction, to build new building detached from the present one, of the character and dimensions shown on plans which we think are most useful, and at the same time the cheapest that can be built.

The Indian Commissioner,

Regina,

Assn.

VERY POOR COPY
We have kept in mind your wish to heat with air, and have made provisions in our plans for the same, to be done by means of a furnace.

To build a chamber good enough to use a stove would be out of the question so we have decided on one of Gurney's furnaces.

I regret that we cannot heat the old building with air, but it being so long and narrow effectually prevents that. But I am glad to state that the new stoves bought last Fall have been amply sufficient to warm the place even in its present state, the fires always lasting all night and the place warm in the mornings, even on stormy days. I think that when we put in ventilators in the school room and dormitories that place will be warm and sweet at all times.

We propose to have washhouse and laundry etc. apart from main buildings.

I think it will be found of great advantage to have boys and girls in different houses, so that they are only within reach of each other at school, meals and prayers.

Dear Sir:

Re: Gordon Indian Reserve Cistern and Water-water.

We have gone into details very carefully in this connection and beg to submit the following to you. Since Mr. Wismer's return and arranging to bring ground pipe line in from the East side along to the cistern, we have made calculation to have the cistern five feet below the ground surface in place of two as according to our original instructions. We trust this is agreeable and understood. We have made provision to have the cistern as per your directions, reinforced with fencing on the walls etc. and three-quarter inch iron on top slab. Also an opening for entering same, labor and material complete $710.80.

With regard to the tile pipe lines leading into cistern, we have marked two little round o's on the first blue print, as the two beginning points for the tile underground drain it will be understood as the two finishing points for the tins workers.

Making provision for 6" glazed pipe well laid and using cement to cork same without running both from the East and West side of the building into the cistern. Also an extra line running from the black O marked near the chimney on the chapel building to take care of the rain water pipe off this building. Also making provision for sixty lineal feet of 10" glazed tile as an overflow pipe from cistern. This we trust will extend far enough away from the building so as not to interfere with the lay of the grounds.

Provision has also been made for a cast-iron vent pipe from the cistern as well and a cistern pump. This all supplied and in a good workmanlike manner comes to $480.15.

Regarding the timework, Messrs. Wismer and English quotation labor and material complete according to plans agreed upon $255.00.

We feel confident that ample provision had been made in every respect to overcome your water difficulty.

Should it be convenient to have this cistern installed on the East side of the chapel in place of on the West as originally planned, also in lieu to the ground being lower on the East side than on the West, this would make less excavation and no doubt you could have the cistern as originally planned running two feet under the surface of the ground. It would also make less excavation for the tile drains as well and would not add any extra to the material. So the excavation alone would make a saving of $90.00.

Thanking you for this valued inquiry and trust same will meet with final approval. Under separate cover we are returning you the plans.

Awaiting your favorable reply, we are,

Yours truly,

A. W. Heise Company Limited,

MEMORANDUM.

MR. SCOTT.

Some time ago, the Reverend Principal of the new Gordon's Indian Boarding School asked to have a soft water cistern built in order to conserve the rain water carried from the roofs, for use in the laundry. He was advised at that time that the matter would be given consideration when the barns were being erected.

Mr. Swan, Inspector of Construction, was written to recently and asked to obtain and submit to the Department, a price for the building of a proposed concrete cistern. He has submitted a price from the contractors for the barn, of $1,400, also a price from Mr. Hemsworth, for $1,200.00, but Mr. Hemsworth would be unable to undertake the work until next year. I would recommend that Mr. Swan be authorized to have the cistern built by the contractors for the school barns, on a cost plus ten per cent basis.

When the water system was provided in building this school, last year, a well was sunk, adjacent to the lake, and it was figured that the water would soak through from the lake to the well, which has not proven satisfactory, and it will therefore be necessary to dig a trench, and fill same with gravel leading from the well to the lake, at an estimated cost of $400.00. This work was not done at the time the water system was installed, as it was hoped that the extra expense might be saved. It is evident, however, that it will be necessary to install this trench, and I would recommend that Mr. Swan be instructed to have this work carried out by the contractors for the barn, on a cost plus ten per cent basis.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am attaching herewith Inspector J.G. McKechnie's report on the Gordon Boarding School, situated on Gordon's Reserve, Touchwood Agency. The report is a good one and the reputation that this school has always had has been kept up.

Mr. McKechnie makes suggestions in regard to Manual Training. I have always thought that we should do a little of this work in schools of this kind. We have certain equipment in the Warehouse here that could be used if we had a proper building in which to install the benches, etc. The Department might consider the question of erecting a small frame carpentry shop, well away from the main building down by the stables, where we could carry on a certain amount of manual work. Of course, the main object of the school should be to train the boys and girls in the line of Agriculture, but it is also necessary that the boys should have a knowledge of carpentry, blacksmithing, etc. This branch of the work has almost disappeared in some of our larger schools, at Qu'Appelle for instance. At one time it was a branch of work that a great deal of attention was given to.

I would strongly recommend that an item of $700.00 be placed in the Estimates, which have just gone forward, for the purpose of building a root house. I think that if we had this amount we could build a root house that would provide ample storage room for the year's supply of vegetables.

Dear Sir,

I have examined the center grate supports in these boilers, and find that they have sagged down and allowed the grates to fall to ash pit floor. This is invariably caused by ashes being allowed to accumulate in the ash pit, and not allowing a free circulation of air to keep the grates cool, or hot coals dropping into the ash pit and causing the same to become so hot that the center support and grates are bound to warp. Care must be taken that the pit is clear of ash at all times, and cleared of ash as often as required, and not at stated times for the reason that different coals require different attention or have more ash, and in the case of the Tofield coal being used at this school, hot coals drop through the grates when the fire is disturbed by firing or otherwise and these will remain a red hot mass for hours. I would suggest that the ash pit be lowered by cutting into the floor below the boiler pits so as to allow a larger volume of air under the grates, but this would be of no use benefit unless kept clean of ash.

In regard to the support that broke last year, I have examined same and can see no flaw in the casting. It is a clean break and I would judge was caused by throwing a shovel full of very wet coal, possibly full of ice and snow, directly on this when it was very hot. Care must be given grates as with anything else.

Yours very truly,

"R. W. Birch?"

Dear Mr. Atwater:

Thank you for your letter of the 16th inst., with further information with regard to the Drumheller Coal. The coal they are using in the large hot-water furnace in the St. Cuthbert's house used as the Theological College here, is Screened Miners Run, from either the Crows Nest mine at Fernie, or some other mine in that locality. The coal used in the large steam furnaces in the St. Chad's College building, now used as the Girls school, is Miners Run unscreened, from the Crows Nest Mine. The latter costs $11.25 per ton delivered, and the former $13.50 per ton. I think it possible you may find the Miners Run unscreened steam coal, to be a more satisfactory coal for a big plant like Gordon's School, and I am satisfied that you could get better prices than we have been paying locally. On the other hand, if you are able to burn satisfactorily, a soft coal, they are very much cleaner to handle, and I think, have less waste in them.

It is unfortunate about the defective building construction, but we find the same in every contract building in the country. The only possible thing we could suggest, is to get the Government to put on "Chamberlain" metal stripping on windows and outside doors, or the "Lockwood" metal stripping on storm sashes. By the use of this metal stripping, we have in the Synod office, cut down our coal bill by one-third. In my opinion, metal stripping of some kind must be used in all public buildings. No doubt there are different kinds on the market, and you could look into the matter and take it up with the Dept.
Rev. H. W. Atwater,

The Apportionment Committee met yesterday and passed an estimate for your stipendiary grant for $900 for 1923. I am sorry to say that we were quite a bit down on our assessment this year owing to financial conditions, and that our overdraft has been increased by $600, on our workings in 1922, but this of course was to be expected. We did not pass any additional vote for Gordon's School, as we did not have any requisition from you to do that. We think it is very wonderful that you have been enabled to finance things in the new building, without indebtedness upon the Government grant, and your excellent management in home produce. But if you think it is necessary for me to apply for an allowance on the 1923 budget, I shall be glad if you will make the items known to me in time for our meeting of the Executive Committee, on January 31st.

SIR,

Will the Department permit me to suggest that, before this new school building is taken off the contractors' hands finally, which, I understand will be done after the year from the time it was finished has expired, that a competent person be sent to inspect it, one who thoroughly understands methods of construction, and installation of heating and lighting plants, and who has no connection, even remotely, with contractors or officials.

I enclose a letter from the chairman of the Indian Committee, and would direct your attention to the second paragraph, in which he makes a suggestion about keeping some of the wind out. I wrote him that it was exceedingly expensive trying to heat all the air on Gordon's Reserve.

Your inspector would see, if he came, that in the engine room, with the dynamo belted to a pulley on a shaft, vertically, instead of being directly belted to the engine, there is a loss of nearly 4 h.p. out of the 10 h.p. which the engine is designed to produce.

He would also see that having the water tanks one on the other instead of side by side, as specified, the air pressure is very...
seriously interfered with.

At any rate, it would pay the Department to ring out the defects in this building, so that they might be guarded against in the erection of another.

Last winter, the fireman placed here by the Department, estimated that one ton of coal a day would suffice to heat the building, but the wood had not then shrunk, as green lumber always will; now, it takes two tons, and for the reason which I gave in the foregoing, the result, when a high wind is blowing, is not all that can be desired.

Dear Sir;

Re. Gordon School, Punnichy.

In accordance with your instructions I have made an inspection of the above school, to ascertain the reason for the Rev. Principal's complaints.

During our most severe weather last winter there was some delay in coal delivery to the school, and the heating plant had to be kept going by using wood, most of which was green. As a result of this some of the pipes froze up; particularly the wet returns from the playrooms. You may remember that I took this matter up with Mr. Orr & Co. October 3rd, 1921.

Regarding the loose windows I find that the sashes have shrunk somewhat, but not more than is usual under conditions in the West; except in one case in the South classroom, where there is a sash that can be actually pulled past the stops. This must either have been planed down since or was overlooked and left a very loose fit at completion of the job. To have perfectly tight windows it would be necessary to put on some form of weather strip.

The plaster has cracked wherever lathed work meets that put direct upon tile or brick. This of course is to be expected on account of the unequal shrinkage. Generally the plaster is in good condition.

Where wooden beams are exposed in kitchen there is quite a little shrinkage where glazed brick is built around the ends of these. A moulding could easily be mitred around these to hide the open joints.

In the Rev. Principal's suite there appears to be more than usual shrinkage between the base and floor, and in this case the shoe strip was nailed to the base instead of to the floor.

Some of the doors have shrunk, but the condition can be remedied by setting the butts out slightly. Solid doors, particularly those of pine or fir, are never free from shrinkage to some extent. The only door to stand up is the veneered door.

1.
The coal bin has pulled away from the boiler room wall much more than it should have done even though it was built during cold weather and after the main walls were up.

The man in charge of the engines states that the generator engine is overloaded due to the fact that there is not a direct drive to the generator. Owing to the lack of room in the generator room a direct drive is no practicable. The day that I made my inspection the engine was running well with generator and all laundry machinery. I was told that the engineer from Punnichy had been out and cleaned it. I afterwards saw this engineer and he explained that the engine had not been properly timed in the first place and he had changed the timer.

I might repeat what I have mentioned in a previous report that the laundry is much too crowded, and with the amount of machinery installed might well have been twice the size.

There appears to have been no further trouble with the grate supports, under heating boilers, sagging.

While in Regina I saw Mr. Smith of Smith Bros. & Wilson, and he promised to come up to Punnichy and go over the building with me and see what could be done to remedy some of the defects. He intends to do this as soon as the roads are fit for car travel.

You will of course understand that all lumber in use in the west will shrink after it is in place.

During the winter months here the buildings are heated to a high temperature with no provisions for humidifying the air with the result that all lumber shows the effects to some extent. In many cases with the return of wet weather and open windows in the spring and summer much of it swells up again. The kiln dried lumber of the present day is not like the ten year seasoned material of some years ago.

For a large building that is practically all lumber construction I consider the amount of shrinkage not more than normal.

When I can get Mr. Smith on the job I shall be able to have some of the items attended to.

If there is any further information that I can obtain for you I shall be pleased to send it.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I wish to bring to your attention a matter that I think requires prompt attention. I refer to the lighting system at the Gordon School in the Touchwood Agency, which was built by Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson.

The storage battery, which cost the Department in the neighbourhood of $2600.00, was put out of commission in six months after it was installed, and since that date up to the present time, the battery has been dormant and useless. This condition was brought about through no other cause whatever than incompetent management on the part of the man who is still in charge of this plant.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Commissioner Graham must have been misinformed concerning the battery of the lighting system in this school, as there is nothing the matter with it. It gives the highest test when fully charged and carries the lights satisfactorily.

I have made complaints about the belting of the engine to a shaft, and dynamo to shaft, instead of direct belting from engine to dynamo. As it is, we get 5 h.p. only, from a 10 h.p. engine, and 2 gallons of oil where 1 gal. would do if proper connections were made.

I applied, on the last occasion, through Ven. Archdeacon Knowles, Chairman of the Indian Committee, to have the proper change made, and he wrote me that the Commissioner would be up, accompanied by an expert, in a week or two. This was in June last.

Dear Mr. Scott:

Sir:

In connection with your letter 121-1-5 of June 16th, with reference to the installation of a telephone at the Gordon School at Punnichy. At this time you state that I may arrange for the installation of a telephone if such can be done for an inconsiderable amount. I beg to inform you that I have not gone on with this work as yet but I have received prices from several telephone contractors and the best price I have received is $200.00 per mile and $35.00 extra for the telephone. The distance from the existing phone line to the school is three miles, but on the way there is a lake which will cause a deviation from the straight line, making the total distance 3½ miles, so the telephone line will cost approximately $685.00.

If funds are available I should be glad to have your authority to go on with the construction of this line.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to inform you that the Principal of the Gordon Residential School has brought to my attention that the windows are very loose in the frames and it will be necessary to put on metal stripping to insure the comfort of the building during the winter, and if this is done naturally it will take less fuel to heat the building. It will take 2800 ft. of metal stripping to do this and will cost approximately $150.00.

He also points out that new grates are required for the furnace and a beam in the firebox which supports the grates.

I would recommend that these expenditures be allowed if at all possible and that I be advised as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham

Sir,

I beg to request that a further sum of $200.00 be authorized for the Principal's residence at Gordon's school to cover the cost of water and sewer connections.

It transpires that the level of the basement floor in the school is about 4' 6" above the basement floor in the residence which will not permit of a sewer connection but will not prohibit the water being taken from that point.

The sewer line from the school however is such as to permit a connection being made about 250' from the residence and for this purpose a trench will have to be dug and vitrified pipe will have to be purchased. With the carpenters and the electrician away all has now been done on the above that can be done until spring; with the exception one or two things which could have been done if I had caught the carpenters before they had left the job i.e. painting the water and soil pipes in the bath room, placing nickel plated floor rings on all pipes in bath room and finishing the white painted wood-work with one coat of white enamel. These items though can be attended to when the painters are on the job in the spring doing the outside painting, as of course none of this was done owing to weather conditions.

There is still a wooden seat to come for the fixture in the bath room.

REGINA, SASK., Dec. 27th, 1926.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I beg to submit the following report on
the Gordon School inspected December 9th, during my
inspection of the Touchwood Agency.

This school is under the management of
the Church of England with Rev. Canon Irwin as Principal.
I found the entire building clean and tidy and all the
departments being carried on with splendid discipline.
The dormitories were clean with plenty of fresh air, and
no offensive odors of any kind. The beds were exception-
ally clean, with a white spread on each.

The laundry is very small and cramped.
The stove which supplies heat for the clothes dryer
smokes so badly that it cannot be used. The smoke gets
into the dryer and makes the clothes dark and smoky.
This must be due to some part being burned out or faulty
drafts and should not be an expensive matter to have
fixed. There is also in the laundry a small soft water
tank; this takes up considerable room and does not begin
to supply even the staff with sufficient soft water.
The children number about 100 and with a staff of 8 to
10, one can understand a lot of washing is necessary,
all of which must be done with hard water. If there is
no available room in the school for a large tank, I see
no reason why a cement under-ground tank could not be
built just outside the school, in which the water from
the entire roof might be collected for use in washing
and especially for bath purposes. This would be a
wonderful help.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
wonderful help to the laundry matron, and by removing the tank now in the laundry, considerable more floor space would be added for carrying on the work of that department.

The senior class room, of which Miss Atwater is in charge, was tidy and well ventilated. The class work was good and the children in the various grades appeared to be well up in their respective grades. I feel that Miss Atwater is doing good work here.

The junior room is in charge of Mr. John Meredith. He is a young man, and, a few minutes in the room was only necessary to see that this man could not handle the situation. He is leaving at the close of this term.

The staff consists of:

| Position          | Name                  |
|-------------------|-----------------------|
| Principal         | Rev. Canon Irwin      |
| Matron            | Miss Atwater          |
| Sr. Teacher       | Miss Atwater          |
| Jr. Teacher       | Mr. J. Meredith       |
| Sewing Teacher    | Miss Wilkins          |
|                   | Miss Howe - just left |
| Kitchen Matron    | Miss Wood             |
| Laundry Matron    | Miss Cunningham       |
| Boy's Supervisor  | Mr. Parsons           |
| Engineer          | Mr. Sworder           |
| Farmer            | Mr. Rogers            |

Miss Howe, one of the two sewing teachers, has just left, but the Principal is endeavouring to fill the vacancy. In addition to the above mentioned, a helper, an Indian, is kept to do work around the barns. All told, there are 11 on the staff and the Indian helper. This appears like a large staff for 100 pupils. As regards the lady members of the staff, I believe they are efficient and are doing good work.

Mr. Meredith has not made a success and is leaving. The Farmer, Mr. Rogers, from what I could learn, is not up to the mark and is handicapped because of deafness.
of deafness. I told Rev. Canon Irwin that I felt he needed a good young man, preferably married, who would take hold of the situation and make a success of it. This, of course, would necessitate another home. He acknowledged Mr. Rogers did not fill the bill and he intended securing another man for Spring. The other man appear to understand their work and Mr. Sworder, the Engineer, keeps everything very tidy and in good repair.

Rev. Canon Irwin, the Principal, is a very energetic and hard working man. He is very determined and I believe has the success of the school at heart. Should he be successful in obtaining the proper teacher and Farming Instructor for the coming year, there is no reason why splendid work should not be accomplished under his direction.

The cattle barn is too small; at present it is necessary to use part of the pig barn to accommodate the young heifers and calves. Fourteen cows are kept in the cow barn and this only supplies milk for the school. The Principal would like this number doubled so that butter could also be made. However, to do this, more barn room will be needed and unless something can be done before another winter, the Rev. Canon Irwin will have to dispose of some of his young cattle, as it is impossible to winter dairy cattle outside. This line of farming I believe to be one of the most important and I would like to see barn room provided so that the natural increase may be cared for and the school herd enlarged.

A new chicken house has been built but is of no use for this climate. There is only one ply of lumber on the walls and this has dried out, so that they are full of cracks. These walls should be covered with good
with good paper and sided up again to make them wind-proof. The front of this building has four windows, two above two. These windows should be lower down and put all across the front of the building so as to allow the sunlight to strike on the floor. Above these windows cotton is needed to allow plenty of fresh air. A cement floor, drop boards and lumber for nests would make this an up-to-date house and of some use. At present no poultry is kept.

A machine shed is badly needed here. These are the boys we expect to be our farmers in the future, consequently, we should educate them to care for machinery and not leave it out in the weather as is done here. When this shed is built, we should bear in mind to build one large enough to cover all machinery necessary to run an institution such as this.

The horse barn is about 24' x 24' and in good repair. However, this barn is small and if any barns are built, this should be kept in mind so that sufficient room, both for horses and increase in cattle be provided for.

At the rear of the school are a number of small buildings which were in use at the time of the construction of the new school. These buildings are all used for various purposes, such as granaries and garage, nevertheless, they do not add to the appearance of the school and should be removed.

The new home built for the Principal was finished except for some painting, and would be ready to occupy at any time. This is a splendid home with a lovely large living room, fireplace, two bedrooms, a bathroom and an enclosed verandah. This should make a comfortable
comfortable and pleasant dwelling.

The children looked exceptionally healthy. They were well clothed and clean. The dinner provided for the children on the day of inspection was well cooked and ample for all. These children appeared very happy and carefree.

While inspecting the school the Principal pointed out the necessity for a telephone in the school. I think he is quite right in his request. This school is about 8 miles from town and many trips could be avoided and a great deal of time saved by the installation of a phone. Of course, in case of sudden or severe sickness, its value could not be estimated.

The Principal complained about the water pipes in the school freezing. He claims the cold gets in around the window frames, especially when a hard wind blows and on the side where the wind strikes the water pipes will freeze in spite of the boilers being fired heavily. One side of the building will be hot, while on the windy side, the pipes will freeze. Several pipes were frozen and broke a few days before I inspected the school, but it seems hard to understand as the temperature would not be lower at that time than 20 below with a wind and if the boilers had been properly fired this should not have happened. I believe the window frames are poorly installed as one could feel quite a draft directly under the windows, even on the day of inspection when only a slight wind was blowing.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report of an inspection on the various schools in the Touchwood Agency, viz: Gordon Indian Boarding School, Day Star Indian Day School, and St. Mary's Day School, all under the auspices of the Church of England, and the Muscowequan Boarding School, situated on the Muscowequan Reserve, and under the auspices of the R.C. Church.

With reference to the Inspector's remarks regarding the laundry in the Gordon School. This laundry is undoubtedly too small for an institution of this kind. I have been in it several times and I came to this conclusion, but there appears to be no remedy for this without incurring a lot of expense. Regarding the stove smoking; it seems to me that the cause of this trouble could be found out by somebody on the ground. They have a practical Engineer in Mr. Sworder who knows his business, and who was Assistant Engineer in one of the large hotels in London up to three years ago, so he should be able to locate this. However, I am writing to the Principal to ascertain if they cannot get this fixed. To send a man from here would cost a lot of money, and I doubt if it is necessary. The soft water tank is very small, and is utterly inadequate to supply the demands for soft water in an institution of this size. I doubt if it would last for a week if used for washing. I may say, however, that the drainage from the large roof on this building would be sufficient to supply the soft water requirements for the school for months, if not for the year around. As it is now, the water runs down to the ground line and is spilt onto a concrete slab which they are having difficulty with, either by it heaving up in the wintertime and getting out of shape, or in summer having a wash underneath and spilling the water up against the foundation, which, of course, is a very bad arrangement. The question of putting in a tile drain to connect with these down-pipes is one that should receive consideration, what I would like to see is

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

to have an outside reservoir built near the laundry, and these down-pipes connected with it. If this were done it would not be necessary to put in the underground tile. Something will have to be done, and for an appropriation of $500.00 I think we could make a good job here, as well as supplying the school with a good quantity of soft water. You are aware that the water for this institution is secured from a small lake, and is not the very best for washing purposes. If the Department would consider placing an item of $500.00 in the Estimates for this purpose I will see that the work is carried out in the Spring.

With regard to the Junior classroom. I know it is the intention of the Principal to replace Mr. Meredith, and I am satisfied that this room will be in charge of a new teacher at the beginning of the term.

On my visit to the School last Spring I pointed out to the school authorities that the Farming Instructor was not the right type of man to carry on the necessary work, and advised them to get a new man. The Bishop of the Diocese and the School Committee have asked me to locate a man and I am trying to do so, but as yet have not been successful. It is difficult to get the right type of man.

The cattle barn at this school is too small, and an amount has been placed in the Estimates to provide additional accommodation. An item of $4000.00 has also been inserted in the Estimates to provide a residence for the Farming Instructor at the School, who should be a married man. With regard to the Inspector's remarks regarding the chicken house. The plan used for this building was one which was received from the University of Saskatchewan, and which we have used at all our schools where chicken houses have been erected during the past two years. The trouble seems to be that they have not adhered to the specifications in erecting this little building. One thickness of lumber is absolutely inadequate. Next Spring a second ply of lumber will be put on the inside and it will then be in accordance with specifications. An item has been placed in the Estimates also for a machine shed. The necessity for this is great. I think when the cattle barn is enlarged the horse barn will be sufficient for the school without making any further additions. The matter of the small buildings at the back of the school which were in use at the time of construction has been drawn to the attention of the Principal and he promised to have them removed in the Spring. I will see that this is done, as they are an eyesore.
You will note that the Inspector reports he found the children looking exceptionally healthy, and that they were well clothed and clean. I may say that this is the way I have found them at all times when visiting the school.

The question of a telephone for the Gordon School has been taken up with the Department from time to time, and last year I urged very strongly to have one installed. An amount has been placed in the Estimates to cover this and I hope it will be passed.

With reference to the remarks regarding the pipes in the school freezing. This is the first time we have had complaints of this nature, although the school has been in use four or five years. We have just passed through some of the worst weather we have ever experienced in this country, and I am of the opinion that the strong winds prevailing during the severe weather accounts for the freezing of the pipes. We may never hear of this again.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to inform you that a great deal of damage is being done by the roof water at the Gordon Indian Residential School. The down-pipes empty onto slabs at the ground level, and these slabs are continually shifting and allowing the water to work its way underneath and into the basement, causing the walls to crack, and steps should be taken to carry this water away from the school.

As you are aware, this school is sadly in need of water. We now have a report from the Provincial Health Department, saying that the water which is now being used at the school is not all that it should be, and it seems to me that the best thing we can do is to construct a large outside tank, which will hold all the roof water caused by the summer rainfall, which water could be used for domestic purposes. I would even go so far as to say that, if necessary, we should neglect other work that is contemplated, in order to get this done. I think this matter was brought to your attention either by letter, or verbally by myself when I was in Ottawa. If this tank is supplied it will serve the dual purpose of taking the roof water away from the foundations of the building, and providing water for use in the school. Great damage will be done if this matter is not attended to before the summer rainfall. The Principal was in the office today to remind me of this. It was brought to my attention while I was at the school last Fall and I asked him to remind me of it this Spring, when I would take it up with the Department.

Yours very truly,
