Filtration

Early Methods:
History shows that there has always been a desire for clean clear water, at least for drinking purposes. The ancients often went to considerable lengths to obtain their water supply from unpolluted springs or water sheds, sometimes at a considerable distance from the town. Roman aqueducts carried large quantities of water, the least best for general purposes, the next best for the fountains and washing troughs and the very best exclusively for drinking purposes.

Where turbid waters were used for drinking water, there is record that porous sandstone and earthenware filters were used by the ancient Egyptians and also by the Romans. There was also a method of clarifying or turbid water by syphoning the liquid from one vessel to another by the capillary action of porous material such as a skin of wool.

Slow Sand Filters:
The practical application of filtration techniques in public supplies probably dates from about 1800. Records show that in about 1810 slow sand filters were installed in Scotland and that in 1829 the Metropolitan Water Board companies installed the first sand filter of this type. The eventual adoption of this system for all of the London water supply, and its use in English cities, led to its being called "The English system" as its use spread throughout Europe.

Slow sand filters are still used to a considerable extent in Europe and also in a number of localities in North America. These filters generally consist of a number of beds of sand varying in size from one-quarter to five acres, usually rectangular in shape, and the slope of the supporting structure is lower than 32 degrees. The fine filter sand is superimposed on three or more layers of graded gravel and is protected by a layer of underdrain either of brick or tile. Each bed is provided with suitable piping to control the influent, effluent, etc.

Some waters may be put onto slow sand filters without any preliminary treatment in the great majority of cases; preliminary settling, sedimentation and sometimes coagulation are used to prepare the water for the filters.

With the slow sand filters an immense surface filtering area is necessary because to obtain the desired result the rate of filtration should not exceed about 50,000 gallons per acre per day—although in some plants the rate is kept half that amount or even less. As the sand used is of rather small grain size and the rate of flow very slow, the filter in itself acts as a clarifier removing all settleable suspended matter. However, with the slow sand filter the surface of the sand bed provides a vast and great number of surfaces to grow and develop. These form an adherent mass that holds back and collects the bacterial and organic impurities. This layer of film (sometimes referred to as the "schmutzdecke") is the active part of the bed and until it has been formed the efficiency of the filter is very low. To "ripen" the filter bed, the slow sand filter is started at about one-tenth of its normal load and then increased gradually so that not until three or four days later is the filter operated at its normal capacity.

Dependent upon the character of the raw water, whether or not it has been given preliminary treatment, rate of flow, and the maximum load of head allowable, etc., the slow sand filter will deliver anywhere from 50,000,000 to 400,000,000 gallons per acre of filter area before cleaning is necessary.

The slow sand filter is cleaned by scraping off the accumulated film of one inch or two of sand from the surface of the bed, the sand being washed and either returned back on the bed immediately or stored in the storage tank and replaced after several scrapings and cleanings.

Slow sand filters are limited in use to small districts with low turbidity and where sufficient ground area is available to provide for the immense filter beds and settling basins.

Rapid Sand Filters:
The first rapid sand or "mechanical" filters were built in the United States during the early 80's. They were installed by the paper industry to solve the problem of removing large volumes of waste and removing the coarser particles of suspended matter that were spoiling their product.

These early filters consisted of cylindrical tanks provided with a simple underdrain underdrain system, a bed of gravel and sand, both water through gravity and pumping. They were not capable of removing the finer or colloidal suspended matter and had but little effect on removing turbidity. However, they readily served their purpose and represented an immense saving therefore because of savings in first cost and space requirements.

Rapid sand filters differ from slow sand filters not only in the rate of flow through the sand bed but also in design, construction and operation. The smaller area of the filter bed, and consequently its much rapid drainage requirements for wash and automatic cleaning. The methods used to quickly wash the sand gave rise to the term "quick wash" or "rapid wash." The high rate of filtration (125,000,000 gallons per acre per day—even more) makes it possible to maintain and operate uniform filter sand—as well as the formation of an "artificial mat" on top the sand bed.

When the introduction of coagulated coagulant is added together the fine suspended matter and to form this artificial mat gave such surprising results it immediately stimulated mechanical improvements. As a result of continual research and improvement the efficiency of the rapid sand filter has steadily increased until today it is the predominating type of filter throughout the world.

These mechanical features in the modern filter might be grouped under the following classifications:

Proper coagulation.
Efficient underdrain systems.
Standardization of sizes and depth of the supporting gravel and filter sand.
Proper size water piping and troughs.
Standardization of rates of filtration and backwash.
Size and arrangement of control piping.
Use of automatic rate controllers, gauges, etc.

To meet all these and other conditions, the modern rapid sand filter bears but little resemblance to its forerunner, the slow sand filter.

Upon adding the coagulant to a turbid water the sludge is immediately flocculated and the finely divided suspended matter quickly settles to the graveled "floor" that settle rapidly—leaving the water fairly clear.

Coagulation:
To operate a rapid sand filter more than a strong coagulant is necessary to use a coagulant to provide an efficient mat on the surface of the filter bed—instead of the slowly accumulated organic slime or "schmutzdecke" of the slow sand filter.

And—if the water is very turbid—the coagulant must be added and sedimentation provided before the water goes to the filter, so as to remove the bulk of the suspended matter outside the filter, otherwise too frequent washing will be necessary.

The common coagulant is alum. Lumps of alum or potash alum in use in pressure coagulant feeders and aluminium sulphate (sometimes termed "alum") when the coagulant is mixed up and fed as a solution.

Practically all waters are alkaline and this natural alkalinity—calcium carbonate and magnesium carbonates decomposes alum with the result heavy white flocculent precipitate of aluminum hydrate. If the water is not naturally alkaline—or its natural alkalinity has been exhausted—by the addition of lime and/or soda ash (in swimming pool filter systems) artificial alkalinity is added in the form of soda ash or lime mixed in the form of sal-soda if a pressure coagulant feeder is used.

The action of the insoluble gelatinous sticky aluminum hydrate can be compared to that of the white of egg in clearing coffee. It entangles all the suspended matter throughout the sand and gathers the finer particles into flocs that can be readily settled, or which are caught on the filter sand, being too large to pass through the spaces between the grains. The coagulant forms a gelatinous mat on the surface of, and in the
upper part of the filter sand, constituting the real filtering medium.

During coagulation, the originally retent or cloudy water undergoes a complete change in appearance, for in place of the murkiness the impurities become coarse grains and flocculent. With them the surrounding water also falls clear. It is then a comparatively simple matter to filter the water.

Underdrain Systems:

The underdrain system of a rapid sand filter serves a twofold important purpose—uniformly distribute the wash water during washing and to collect the filtered water without loss of sand. The underdrain actually consists of the gravel layers and the distributing manifold system.

Aside from supporting the sand bed—the gravel layers—its function is to distribute the wash water and many cases of faulty filter operation can be traced to improperly graded, poor quality gravel layers or grading systems.

To uniformly collect the filtered water—but more important—to uniformly supply the wash water to the undersides of the gravel layers for purpose of the distributing manifold. The systems in common use are:

A pipe manifold system with bronze "strain- ers" or orifice nozzles screwed into the tops of the lateral pipes and laterals.

A pipe manifold system with the pipes perforated on the underside in either single or double rows.

The "Wagner Bottom"—distributing pipes with bronze plates interspaced by slotted perforated concrete blocks.

Concrete "hill and valley" with perforated bronze plate or perforated pipe in bottom of valley.

The "Wheelbar Bottom" with balls geometrically placed in pyramidal hoppers.

"Strainers" or orifice nozzles in false metal or concrete bottoms.

Gravel Layers:

In order to properly support the filter sand, the gravel grains must be small enough at the top layer, and to diffuse the wash water—must be fairly large at the lowest layer—therefore on top must be finer than below. Each grading must be of fairly uniform size and practically free from flat pieces. The gradation must be such that no small pebbles from falling through lower layers.

Modern practice calls for as many as five and sometimes of three gradations ranging in size from \(2\frac{1}{4}\) inches at the bottom to \(1\frac{1}{8}\) inch diameter at the top.

Filter Sand:

Silica sand, which was the first material used, is still the accepted filtering medium of today. Creede quartz, crushed granite, china clay, and screened anthracite coal have also been used—but usually to take care of some special conditions. Porous filter materials are to be avoided as they cannot be washed clean and are breeding places for bacterial growth.

Whereas little attention was formerly paid to the quality and uniformity of filter sand, experience has proven that for proper results definite standards must be laid down and this filtering medium must pass rigid tests and specifications.

Sand performs its function as a filtering medium through its ability to hold back the coagulum or floe containing the suspended and colloidal impurities in the water. Theoretically, the sand should perform this filtering duty, and it is assumed in practice that none of the coagulum penetrates beyond a depth of six inches. In practice, however, continuous tests provide a depth of sand of from 18 to 24 inches in industrial filters, to as much as 30 inches in municipal plants. The latter extreme has not been required by the dictates of some boards of health or the individual practice of some engineers.

The sand bed must be so graded as to be easily channelled or broken through during filtering and yet not so dense as to offer unnecessary resistance to the flow of water.

Suitability of a sand as a filtering medium depends upon its chemical character, freedom from impurities, degree of uniformity of size, and its uniformity. Unless it is of uniform size the smaller grains will pack in the voids between the larger grains and present resistance to the flow of water. Well rounded grains are considered preferable to sharp grains because the former do not pack so readily and clean much better.

Two measures are used to draw a fairly accurate picture of the size and grading of filter sand. These two measurements are the Effective Size and Uniformity Coefficient.

By "Effective Size" is meant the size of the sand grains—usually expressed in weight fractions—of sand finer than which 10% by weight of the sand is finer and 90% coarser. Thus the "Effective Size" is the minimum size of the great bulk of the sand grains but it does not indicate either the limits of coarseness or the degree of variation in the size of the particles.

Therefore, in order to assure that the variation is not too great a second measurement of the sand is necessary. This is the size of sand grains than which 60% by weight of the sand is finer and 40% coarser. This size is determined by the "Uniformity Coefficient" and is called the "Uniformity Coefficient."

For example, if a screen analysis showed that 10% of a sand was finer than 0.40 millimeter, and 60% was finer than 0.64 millimeter—the "Effective Size" would be 0.40 mm., and the Uniformity Coefficient would be 0.64 divided by 0.40 or 1.6. Obviously, the more uniform the sand, the more nearly will be the "Effective Size" which 10% finer and than which 60% is finer—or the closer will be the "Uniformity Coefficient" to 1.0.

The most desirable "Effective Size" and "Uniformity Coefficient" depend upon the conditions of filter operation and the quality of filter sand desired. Modern practice calls for at least two gradings of filter sand. International filters are equipped with a sand of Effective Size of from 0.35 to 0.55 mm.—as conditions warrant—and a "Uniformity Coefficient" of from 1.0 to 1.6.

When a filter is washed, the entire sand bed rises and grades itself—the finest particles on top grading down to the coarsest at the bottom—thus such sand automatically produces the several size condition that is most desired.

Chemical Requirements:

The filter bed must be insoluble in water and the usual specification for filter sand and gravel is that it shall not lose more than \(1/5\) of its weight when heated with hydrochloric acid solution for 24 hours. This is principally to insure the absence of limestone, which, on account of its relative softness and appreciable solubility, would not stand up under agitation during washing.
Rates of Filtration:

The maximum rate of filtration depends upon the required quality of filtered water, the character and quantity of the filter sand and the character of the water to be filtered. Water can be forced through a pressure filter at enormous rates if sufficient pressure is applied but the water will become extremely turbid at excessive rates the water will hardly be "strained," the coagulant will be washed down into the sand and the sand bed ultimately clogged.

For efficient operation and proper quality of effluent, the rate of filtration should be carefully controlled against fluctuations in load. Standard practice has set a rate of from two to three gallons per minute per sq. ft. of filter area as a minimum. Higher rates or higher rates may be required or allowable under special conditions.

The approved specifications for pressure water filters as approved by the American Waterworks Association and the American Society of Mechanical Engineers give the following rates of filtration as standards:

Whenever the water is to be used for domestic purposes or for stock, full flow rates of the capacity of the filter based on a rate of filtration not to exceed 2 gallons per minute per sq. ft. of filtering area and a coagulant must be used.

Rates of filtration for various uses should conform to the following schedule:

- 2 gals. per sq. ft. per minute for all supplies used for drinking, or for the preparation of food products.
- 2 to 4 gals. per sq. ft. per minute when filtering a treated municipal supply of approved bacterial purity.
- 6 to 8 gals. per sq. ft. per minute for swimming pools and for all industrial uses.
- 2 to 5 gals. per sq. ft. per minute as conditions require for rapid filtration using sand followed by charcoal where reduction of color, odor, taste or certain forms of iron is desired. This method of filtration is not to be applied for bacterial purification.

Washing:

Provision for proper washing of the sand bed is equally as important as the design of the filter. The filter retains what is removed from the water and will continue to work satisfactorily only so long as it is properly washed. A filter cannot run until the sand bed is allowed loss of head is reached—or until the desired rate can no longer be maintained. Therefore, at regular intervals the filter must be shut out of service, the waste valve opened and water—preferably filter wash water—allowed to the unfiltered system at a rate sufficient to expose or float the sand bed, to scrub or scour the sand and wash out any accumulated impurities.

From three to eight minutes washing are required to clean the sand bed—with six minutes an average time. From one to five per cent of the total filter filtrate is the normal volume of wash water used—with three per cent an average.

Pressure Filters:

The use of pressure filters is as old as the practice of sand filtration. The term "pressure" is used to designate that type of rapid sand filter wherein the filter is placed in a closed tank or vessel in which the water passes under pressure. This does not mean that high pressure is required to pass the water through the sand bed; it merely indicates that pressure consumed is not more than five pounds at its maximum, with a minimum of about one pound directly across the filter's washer.

In comparison with gravity or open rapid sand filters, the pressure type offers certain advantages. Any connection may be made in any pressure line without loss of pressure for water distribution excepting the connection to the filter tank mentioned above. Remounting of the water after being filtered is not required. They may be quickly installed in any location and easily fit into some available space. Settling basins and clear water storage can frequently be eliminated. Less precision in operation is demanded. The first cost is lower.

Sedimentation:
While comparatively few waters require sedimentation in connection with International Pressure Filters, it can be accomplished easily with very small filters. The purposes of preliminary sedimentation are to allow suspended and coagulated matter to settle, to provide time for the floe to grow, and to relieve filters of a large amount of work (at least 80 percent), thereby reducing the washing of filters to a minimum.

Coagulation:
Coagulation and filtration are very intimately related in the art of water purification. The use of a coagulant in connection with the pressure filter is essential if it is desired to remove all suspended matter visible to the naked eye. The spaces between the sand grains of the filter bed are sufficiently large to allow the finer particles to pass through the filter. In order to retain all the suspended matter on the filter bed it is necessary that the particles be brought together into comparatively large particles. This is accomplished by introducing a coagulant, alum, by means of the coagulant feeder. The small amount of alum fed into the water is extremely important and determined by the alkalinity naturally present in the water and which may be added. The chemical reaction which takes place reduces hydrate of alumina to heavy, solid gelatinous precipitate. At the same time the electrolytic force set free induces the finer particles to gather together in floes, each of which becomes enveloped in the sticky hydrate of alumina.

International Gravity Coagulant Feeder:
An automatic pressure coagulant feeder is furnished with each International Pressure Filter. The feeder is attached to the filter inlet, a special proportioner being placed in the water line. This proportioner automatically bypasses a small percentage of the incoming water through the feeder, in this way the coagulant is dissolved, automatically fed and mixed with the water entering the filter bed.

The International Pressure Coagulant Feeders are of the quick opening design for convenience in recharging. Artificial Alkalinity:
When the filter is to be used in connection with circulating and chlorinated water for swimming pools, an extra feeder should be used. Redfiltration of the water finally exhausts the natural alkalinity of the water and unless artificial alkalinity in the form of soda ash is supplied, the coagulant floc is not formed and free alum will pass through the filter. For such work where there is no natural alkalinity, the use of two feeders, one for alum and one for soda ash, is to be recommended.

International Distributing Manifold System:

The only practical distributing manifold for use with pressure filters is the one manifold consisting of a main pipe with distributing lateral pipes. The size of the pressure filter units and the steel tank construction do not readily permit distributing systems such as the Wagner precast concrete block bottoms.

False bottoms of steel plate unless fitted with special rubber gaskets pull up or settle, so that it is impossible to keep orifice nozzles or "strainers" from working loose and blowing out during washings. When properly perforated in place of using strainers, the upward jet action during washing will displace the gravel layer.

To provide perfect collection of filtered water and uniform distribution of wash water from all points directly under the surface of the filter bed the International manifold of the pipe mainfold type. The header pipe is oversized and the lateral pipes, spaced not less than 6 inches center to center, are of a size larger than the cross area of the filter. The orifice nozzles reach lateral. To meet certain conditions, the manifold system may be of the perforated lateral type, where the pipes are spaced wider center to center, are made in the underside of the lateral pipes and the jets are set flush to the concrete floor of the filter. Jet action is created by the water striking the concrete floor and diffusing between the gravel layer and passing upward through the gravel layers.

The standard manifold system on International general purpose pressure filters is of the pipe mainfold type with International Umbrella Type Tobin Bronze Distributing nozzles. Header and lateral pipes are oversized and the jets are spaced not less than 6 inches center to center. The jets are screwed into the top of the lateral. The correct sub-fill of the filter is brought up to imbed the lateral system and provide a smooth floor under the gravel.

International Tobin Bronze Distributing Nozzle:

The International Umbrella Distributing Nozzle was developed as a true strainer that would accomplish every required result—to stand abuse and wear under all operating conditions—and to eliminate the common faults of ordinary "strainers."

It is made in but two pieces—the body and the cap—both parts of genuine Tobin bronze. The body is a drop forging of solid bronze and rivets are an integral part of the body—and of real riveting metal. The cap is of one piece, scientifically shaped with a central deflecting cone and umbrella edge—both perfectly formed (or efficient distribution) and rivets are spun (not hammered) to assure a perfect joint between cap and body. The throat accurately bored to exact diameter prevents the edge to insure easy influx. The shank is accurately threaded 3/8 inch pipe thread by automatic dies. The cap is a separate part and easily permits the use of a standard wrench for installation.

The term "strainer" to describe this part of the underdrain system is now a misnomer. Before it was learned that proper grading and correct grading of gravel was necessary to keep the sand layer in its proper place—many forms of actual sand strainers were used—and many are still being offered today. With correct gravel grading and the distributing manifold system of efficient design and construction, there will be no possibility of upsetting the gravel layer allowing sand and gravel bottom of the filter. The purpose of the "strainer" of today is not to stop the passage of sand—but is that of providing distribution of wash water under the entire bottom of the gravel layer.

A few of the principal advantages of the International Umbrella Type Nozzle are:

It has but one inside edge—which will not clog or become incrust—strainers with multiple orifices tend to invariably clog within a comparatively short time.

It provides perfect diffusion by the cone-umbrella cap, distributing the wash water in all directions with practically "no away," yet extremely low friction loss and assuring complete diffusion throughout the gravel layer and the gravel layers. Multiple orifice strainers produce a jet action, either upward or partly upward into the gravel layer, and produce a limited number of jets—which puts the responsibility of diffusion on a smaller part of the gravel bed and makes distribution less reliable achieved.

Being constructed entirely of Tobin bronze it is far superior in its resistance to corrosion than other strainers made of any other "acid bronze."

The barrel and its rivets—being a forging—is more homogeneous and smoother than the variable cast base of ordinary strainers—and the rivets are much more uniform and ductile. The rivets being an integral part of the forging will never work loose.
Operation:

Water enters the International Filter through the top and flows uniformly over the filter bed by a baffle, which prevents the incoming water directly striking the sand bed and disturbing the surface film. The water passes downward through the filter and upward the clean filtered water uniformly collected from beneath the gravel by the manifold system, throughout the passage of the filter outlet.

To remove the collected sediment or suspended matter, the filter is periodically cleaned by reversing the flow of water. Wash water enters at the bottom, is first distributed by the manifold system, further distributed by the umbrella distributor, and finally distributed over the gravel layers. As the water rises the filter bed expands and is loosened, the sediment lifting and passing out to waste with the wash water.

Rate of Flow Controller:

Although not furnished as standard equipment, pressure filters of all types and makes should be provided with automatic rate of flow controllers, especially if partial bacterial purification is expected or the water is to be used for domestic supply—and for the better general operation of the filter plant. It is evidently a gravity filter installation that is made without rate of flow control and underloading of a pressure filter is so much more possible that there is even greater reason for automatic control.

Depending upon the piping arrangement, the rate of flow controller is placed in either the inlet or outlet line of the filter. The International Rate of Flow Controller is of the Venturi type, the differential head automatically controlling the movement of the mercury device so that the filter cannot deliver a greater amount of water than that determined by the setting on the controller. With other filter equipment, controllers are built handling its proper share of the load, whereas a clean filter of a battery of filters will always deliver twice as much or three times the pressure until the other filters have been cleaned.

Many modern filter plants are providing International Type P Rate of Flow Controllers to assure the proper amount of water during backwashing.

These controllers may be provided with International Rate of Flow Gauges, either indicating or recording. Both the controllers and gauges are the subject of a separate bulletin.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of file 312-11A C.W.
of the 11th inst., I have made an analysis of the sample of water
from the Indian Residential School at Punnichy, with the
following results:

| Parts per million | Grains per gallon |
|-------------------|-------------------|
| Sulphate          | 403               |
| Carbonate         | 191               |
| Chloride          | 51                |
| Calcium           | 37                |
| Magnesium         | 147               |
| Sodium            | 52                |

Magnesium sulphate is the principal mineral
salt present accordingly, and therefore this water would probably
be somewhat of an irritant laxative. I would suggest that in
addition to installing equipment to remove organic matter and
contamination, this water should be softened for drinking, as
well as other uses, by a zeolite softening plant. Since the
effectiveness of different zeolite softening plants varies con-
siderably, I would suggest that you see that the plant installed
is unreservedly guaranteed by the manufacturer to completely
soften the water, without unduly increasing the total of mineral
salts present.

Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) J. Grant Lewis,
Analytical Chemist.

Sir:

When forwarding you the report by Travelling Nurse Miss E. Phin of her visit in June to the Gordon's School, I referred to certain unsanitary conditions to which she had drawn attention.

I have received a letter from Mr. William Swan at Punnichy, stating that there appears to be a constant slow stoppage and backing up of water in the toilet rooms which can only be temporarily remedied by flushing the drain with the fire hose. The kitchen sink he also found to be giving trouble and that cannot be used at all, notwithstanding that the trap and grease trap have both been removed and thoroughly cleaned without effectually remedying the trouble. Mr. Swan suggests that the plumbers who put in the job be authorized to proceed to the school and look over the various troubles, and I beg to request the authority to so instruct Messrs.
